text:
Right now, we are dealing with a multilateral disaster, climate change, our greatest threat in thousands of years. If we don‚Äôt take action, the collapse of civilization and the extinction of our natural world are on the horizon. The people of the world have spoken, and their message is clear: time is running out. Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere are now 50 percent higher than they were in 1900.

The world has become so fragile that we cannot subject the Earth to the tortures we can now inflict upon it. We are tampering with the climate of the Earth and the atmosphere we breathe. Not only are we piling carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, but we are chopping down the forests of the Earth at a great rate. These problems are life and death problems. 

They go to the root of the viability of the planet itself, making the Earth a lot less livable! We are dealing with issues that cut across national boundaries. When we talk about the greenhouse effect, we are talking about something that affects the entire planet. The world must band together to address the challenges and concerns as a whole. A human solution is the only way to solve a problem. 

One thing about the human species that is biologically certain is that it is a human species. ONE species. Who is going to fight? Who is going to lead in the directions? Never can we sit back and wait for miracles to save us. Miracles don‚Äôt happen. Sweat happens, effort happens, thought happens. Have all that happen. Why should we care about climate change? It‚Äôs not just an existential threat to be overcome. It‚Äôs an opportunity for humans to unite around a common cause.

text:
There is a contradiction in this video.
0:48 fear & guilt are not conducive to engagement

The case study of how communications plan in ozone holes succeded to engage people =
2:17 skin cancer: fear
2:52 stop buying CFC products: guilt

I think the reason why this contradiction exists and why is it hard to engage people in climate plan is not only because of the way we communicate. First, global warming seems like something that only happened in the future and only indirectly affecting them (e.g polar bears and developing countries). While the ozone hole seems like something urgent because it's already happened and it can causes skin cancer to anyone. Second, people can only choose what's affordable (in terms of price, accessibility, etc) to them.

In ozone hole, you can just not use CFC products which is less urgent than what you have to lose if you want to help global warming. In global warming, there can be so much that you can do yet it can be such a drastic change depending where you live, what can you buy, etc. Hence why, rather than highlighting sporadic individual change, we should highlight the system that we built in first.

In ozone holes, if elites ready to lose the CFC company sales, then individual will accordingly adapt to it. In global warming, if elites ready to let unsustainable energy go like coal and oil, then individual will also adapt though needs much more help.

Grassroots need to be included in climate plan. However, before governments, corporations, and other stakeholders take revolutionary actions other than making as if the burden of saving the entire earth is only in individual's shoulder, it's not going to do much.

text:
The consumer can only do so much. Our lives are supported by technology. Big corporations need to be pushed by governments to do more to have an impact on global warming. I can reduce my energy usage and carbon emissions I create and I do where possible, but I still need electricity/car/etc. to a live a modern life and have a stable job. It's all one big cycle that needs breaking. 

For example, I'd love an electric car, but even then, producing the materials to build an electric car (or any car) produce huge amounts of greenhouse emissions and I will still have to charge it (for the long journeys I do in particular) at a charging point that is fed by electricity from fossil fuels being burnt. Of course not to mention the fact that I (and many others) can't afford an electric car right now! I would however happily give up my car if electric public transport was being offered which would be a lot cheaper.

Governments need to do far more to work together to put money into research for clean production of energy and raw materials and also to force massive corporations to fund more research and change their ways right at the core of the problems. It's just easier for them all to push the problem away and to just take tiny steps, to look good in the media and get voted in again, until it's too late and we have a bigger problem on our hands... Hmm reminds me of a certain global pandemic that was predicted for decades...

text:
TimeLapse Among the lies pedalled by the wind industry is that wind turbines run on the smell of an oily rag and last for more than 25 years.
The pitch is made to beguile the gullible (read, ‚Äòplanning authorities‚Äô, ‚Äòpoliticians‚Äô, ‚Äòbankers‚Äô and ‚Äòinvestors‚Äô) into believing that their operating costs can be covered out of petty cash ‚Äì which fits with the other great line about there being nothing as ‚Äòfree‚Äô as the wind.
Mechanical wear and tear, including bearing failure is one of the most common reasons for turbines to be put out of action; and is one of the key factors that accounts for the fact that the ‚Äòeconomic‚Äô life of wind turbines is 10-12 years, which runs contrary to wild claims about them lasting for ‚Äú25-plus years‚Äù (see our post here and this paper).
Top flight German turbine maker, Siemens booked a ‚Ç¨223 million write down (ie loss) in 2014 due to the fact it had to replace bearings in a fleet of turbines that were less than 2 years old.
Siemens talking about the loss said: ‚ÄúThe charge is related to inspecting and replacing bearings due to the early degradation in certain turbine models. We believe this is related to recent batches of bearings and we are in discussions with the supplier‚Äù (see our post here).
And Siemens‚Äô ‚Äòluck‚Äô has been no better in the US, where its ‚Äì barely-out-of-nappies ‚Äì turbines literally fell apart in the Californian desert: 2 Year Old Siemens Turbines Falling Apart: Wind Farm Investors, Get Out While You Can
Siemens aren‚Äôt having any better luck closer to home.
In Denmark, the √òrsted offshore wind farm at Anholt was completed in 2013. Barely 5 years later and the turbines‚Äô blades are so worn out that hundreds of them need to be dismantled, returned to dry land and repaired.  Denmark also has the highest energy costs on the planet most of if not all of the windmills will have to be replaced after only 25% of the usage windmills are not reliable

text: "By 1987, in response to a dramatic seasonal depletion of the ozone layer over Antarctica, diplomats in Montreal forged a treaty, the Montreal Protocol, which called for drastic reductions in the production of CFCs. On 2 March 1989, 12 European Community nations agreed to ban the production of all CFCs by the end of the century." It's not about individual change. It's not because a percentage of consumers decided to stop using CFC aerosols that the Ozone hole stopped growing. Governments took action and BANNED CFCs. You can't get them anymore, even if you wanted to. We need to have the same decisiveness today! It's not that individuals are scared of the type of messaging. If you look into global warming and compare the impact of household electricity vs food waste, planned obsolescence, non-green energy production, oil production, the meat industry... There's only so much individual consumers can do. Industry and governments need to change!

text:
Our current recycling processes desperately need to be renovated in many places around the world though. Way too much stuff slips out without the common public knowing, and the actual processing is often still quite polluting. Not to mention that lots of plastic types cannot be recycled anyway.. It really should be the second to last resort whenever dealing with unusable stuff. It's basically the step before throwing stuff away. Reducing, reusing, and composting should be considered long before the recycling step. 

Seriously though, can people please stop sending recycling waste to Recycling Centers located ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE GLOBE. All recycling plants should be somewhat local to prevent unnecessary emissions from shipping.

text: I am annoyed with how this video individualizes the problem of climate change. Almost puts the blame on our individual uses of water, electricity, etc. when multi billion dollar companies are responsible for much of the emissions, environmental pollution, and the stemming societal problems. In a capitalist system these companies will keep exploiting the land until there is nothing left and it‚Äôs us that will reap the consequences. Just look at how they are going to start drilling in the Arctic Refuge. Yes it‚Äôs useful for each of us to live a more sustainable lifestyle, but all of these climate change communication researchers focus on how to make the individual change their lifestyle rather than how to get the individual to recognize the issue with how our current capitalist society functions and researching what can lead the individual to go protest. This is Probably because the answer is to overthrow the government in some sort as our current system was built upon the colonialist ideals of manifest destiny and white supremacy. I call for these researchers to shift their focus away from this neoliberal perspective.

Don't forget that our planet has gone through various cycles of warming and cooling before humans existed. Some aspects of the ice ages that occured are not fully understood yet. I still thing we've done other things to this planet that is contributing greatly to climate change well beyond emissions.

text:
Lots of people are lazy. They say not to worry because 2050 is an "exaggeration" or it's "really far in the future" and therefore isn't a big deal. SO WHAT? Minimizing the effects of global warming, even if the real impact is a century from now, should be important to more people. Lots of humans are also too selfish to give up things they've grown used to (eating animal products every day, traveling annually,  supporting corporations that are bad for the environment solely because they make money) in order to fight climate change.

People in who have the most influence have the choice to not listen to any of this stuff. Humans can make as many factually-backed claims, write as many scientific articles, and actively try to make as much of a difference as possible, but the people in power can choose to ignore it (as seen in the recent years, some of them have been).

text:
Humans are bottom of the barrel learners. We all hit rock bottom and the majority of us bounces back in one way or another. We just need a shake in our foundation.

So I believe it will get much worse before it gets better. We all collectively need to hit rock bottom before we can change the way we live. We are already in spiral. 

We arent killing earth, because it can take a meteor and not care. We are killing ourselves and our opportunities. I doubt humans will  ever go extinct by our own actions, but we are going to lose alot. Life is far more resilient than we believe.

I just hope we learn and get better from our mistakes. 

Enjoy life and contribute something to this world! Because one day it is going to change and you will lose that opportunity to make your mark. Give people more credit and be nice to each other.

text:
One of the important takeaways of this vid is the complexity of climate change. 
We CAN'T oversimplify and say, "the REAL issue with climate change is ..." and insert a single issue or bad-guy.
It's a problem with many interconnected issues and we have to be smart enough to treat it as such. Be smart enough to see and tackle it with multiple strategies on multiple levels like geo-political, mass-behavioural, legal, punitive, activist, technical, UX, empirical-analytical, social, media, cultural, educational, awareness, motivational, psychological, etc. that can all reinforce - not compete - with one another. And resist the urge to reduce climate change to a single issue with a single quick-fix that may be easily refuted by others or even oneself.

text:
There are simple things that you can do like zero waste, however, I suggest transitioning to it slowly since it can overwhelm you quickly. It can also be expensive depending on where you live. Where do you live btw? Your name is def Middle Eastern. If you live in Kuwait I could rec you places and shops. 

- Refuse plastic straws
- Bring your own container if unable to finish restaurant food
- Use reusable produce bags and totes instead of single- use ones. You can make them out of unused pillow cases or clothes
- Bring your own water bottle and/or coffee/tea tumbler
 - Shop in bulk whenever you can
- Reduce your intake of animal products 
- For periods, get either a diva cup or reusable pads. I personally use the latter. 
- Use shampoo bars/conditioners instead of bottled ones (I still haven't personally found a conditioner bar that works for me yet).
- Make your own deo if possible 
- Compost kitchen scraps

text: Any producer of energy cannot produce more energy than it consumes.  That is the foundation of the law of conservation of energy.  Thus, any energy-producing engine requires efficiency.  Traditional means can employ intermittent heat sources, chambers for combustion that employ pistons which in turn drive spinning wheels that break magnetic "cling."  This is then harvested by a cathode and anode system as an electric conversion.  In order to solve global warming issues, there must be a producer of energy at peak-efficiency or a perpetual motion machine that breaks the laws of energy conservation.  Any laws passed concerning global warming will, thus, fall on the consumer and they would be required to consume less energy.

text:
Pollution is a real problem and needs to be addressed especially as the world's human population continues to rise.  CO2 is not a pollutant, in fact is an essential food for all photosynthesizing plants, and photosynthesizing plants are in a CO2 drought!  At concentrations of 900 to 1200 ppm, CO2 would increase the health and growth of all plants dramatically.  C3 plants would be happier with even higher concentrations.


There is very little correlation between CO2 and global temperature.  When it is correlated, CO2 always FOLLOWS global temperature, not the other way around -- ALWAYS.


Help photosynthesizing plants out all over the world by CLEANLY creating much more CO2!  Best estimates is that anthropomorphic (human created) CO2 is in the low single digit percentage of the atmospheric CO2 (a trace atmospheric gas).  Do your part to help green the globe (shown in NASA satellite photography) by emitting as much clean CO2 as you can!

text:
Frankly, electricity only makes up 20% of our total energy consumption. Sure, we can and should reduce electricity consumption, but a more important question is maybe: how can we convince companies and goverments to switch to renewable energy? Solar & wind energy is already significantly cheaper than burning coal. 

However, going back to my first point, our BIGGEST problem is: what do we do with the other 80% of energy use? The use of fossil fuels is embedded in the way we move people and stuff (cars, airplanes, container ships), the things we eat (meat production is a huge contributor to climate change) and the products we use (plastics, concrete or steel for example). For most of these things we still have no clue how to transform these systems to sustainable ones. 

We need loads of research & development, and loads of people who are concious of the enormous challenge we're facing. At least that is going in the right direction the last few years. But there's a long road ahead...

text: I mean I'm from Denmark, a country which as some may know is very active in working against climate change, and I think the Things that worked to get Danes onboard were that we looked at the problem early enough, and a single key source. We started making policies and laws in regards to climate change early enough that the problem seemed relatively fixable in a shorter time period, plus we got kids onboard a short time after, teaching about the dangers and effects of climate change. And while there are a lot of bad stuff, Ice caps and glaciers melting and potentially putting the entire country underwater, and the threat of entire species dying, causing the ecosystem to fall apart. But all of that could be tied down to a single thing. Greenhouse gasses, primarily carbon dioxide of course, which would come from fossil fuels like those used in our cars and power plants. So we saw a way to change it there. If we could switch entirely to green energy consumption, we could potentially save us all from destruction! We already had a head start thanks to investing in wind power following the oil crisis, so that definitely helped make the problem more approachable! Since then other issues have popped out, but we've managed to get by, thanks to focusing on the core things I guess.

text: Yeah, no. This pseudo-psychological analysis is lazy. People can be motivated to address issues that can concern their survival, and at this point other types of messaging that are more 'hopeful', 'progressive' and 'optimistic' have already been tested. It's time for radical change, and radical messaging. It's not about people reacting to climate news anymore. It's about people themselves realizing this is a core issue in their lives, and starting to get angry and frustrated and hopeless all at the same time about their generation's future. And those emotions are the catalyst we need. Because guess what? People do care today, and people are good at thinking about climate change. It's just a matter of implementing these issues into action and policy-making, and cracking down on the major players that are recklessly ruining whole ecosystems and communities for their own benefit.

Why can't businessmen find a way of making huge money with renewable fuels and electricity? It is an opportunity which the enterprising can certainly make the most of. Or invest in these as a complementary economic good? 



Can we do without refrigerators? Yes some of us can, because we have home delivery of perishables everyday or we can pick up small quantities every day. This is especially true for retired persons who do not live far from shopping complexes. Its not that tough to change. As for animal agriculture...You don't have to eat cows pigs and goats you know! the video is a bad premise.  we're bad at thinking about lots of things because our media is a blend of lies, distraction, confusion & other unhelpful stuff.  3 years after Britains Brexit began - 3 years of non-stop 7 day a week Brexit coverage on the TV - & still no-one's the wiser about the actual substance of britains relationship with the EU.   what are we leaving?  what are we putting in it's place?  which of our models or theories best describes the current british-EU relationship in a way that covers most of its complexity?  we literally have nothing like this at all.  we're not even thinking on this level.


TV (especially the BBC) do not cover things in a way that's breeds understanding, in any way.  i'm not even sure they know how at this point.  lies & misdirection seems to be all they're capable of.

author: Hg Pb

text: ¬†@Hg Pb¬† Good thinking; but if CO2 was black the atmosphere would be opaque.   It already is, to the wavelengths that CO2 can absorb.  But it also re-emits, which means it is both "black" and "white" at the same time.  Its warming power is the latency between these; how long can it hold a photon of energy?   But most of the time near the surface it transfers the absorbed energy by collision with another molecule and consequently does not radiate.  This is an important factor in warming.  Conversely, at TOA (Top of Atmosphere), CO2 is free to radiate into space where other atmospheric molecules cannot.  The result is CO2 cools the TOA, but warms the BOA (surface).  Its actual contribution is rather limited, about 5 percent of the total greenhouse effect, but it is that 5 percent that some think ought to be adjusted.
author: Thomas Maughan

text: ¬†@Thomas Maughan¬† If it was black enough to appear only in high concentrations found in areas with large volumes of co2 produced constantly then it would have been dealt with.

text:
Attempting to bastardise an established term "climate change" to mean "man made climate change"is the killer. 

A news item saying "it's down to climate change" invokes a different response to the phrase "it's down to man made climate change". The former gets a shrug of the shoulders because everyone understands the climate changes the latter provokes a question - "how do you know man has caused the change?"


And that's when the tap dancing starts and Joe Public turn away in their droves muttering "shysters". It's really that simple

text: The video isn't quite right. It suggest that people simply stopped using aerosol spay products and that solved the problem. The truth is that aerosol spray can use totally different propellants than they used to in the 1960s and early 70s. Back then they used CFCs, which some scientist attributed to causing the hole in the ozone layer. Those were banned a LONG time ago. Nowadays all aerosol spray cans use something totally different, usually propane or butane. These types of aerosol spray cans can't possibly do any damage to the ozone layer. So, you can use all the aerosol spray products you want and not be worried one bit that you are going to damage the ozone layer, unless you just happen to have a 60 year old can of hairspay that still works.

text:
¬†@Ani Goel¬† "without coral reefs, there's no fish, no sharks, the ocean creates oxygen too, not just trees, and lots of people eat fish."

That's both unlikely and simple minded.  The oceans have been higher, lower, warmer, colder.  Coral would have been extinct but it isn't and obviously adapts.  Those kind of fish, such as Clownfish if I remember right, that depend on coral will go extinct if coral itself goes extinct.   
Plankton in the oceans create oxygen but to do that they also require carbon dioxide, same as any plant.  Fish depend on that oxygen so it is pretty much neutral as far as benefit to land animals goes.

author: Thomas Maughan

text:
¬†@Marmex¬† You made a claim that 90 percent of oxygen was made from oceans.  I responded; but not perhaps to your liking.  Your parameters are unspecific.  Do you claim that 90 percent of atmospheric oxygen now existing was sourced from plankton?  That is not a "fact".  Oceanic oxygen production is almost entirely consumed by oceanic life; just as terrestrial oxygen produced by trees and grasses is consumed by terrestrial life.  
Now if you are referring to oxygen containing minerals such as the White Cliffs of Dover, made of calcium carbonate, then perhaps the 90 percent makes some sense since for a very long time, billions of years, there was no terrestrial life and oxygen was actually a poisonous byproduct.   Water is simply oxidized hydrogen and pre-dates plankton.
author: Thomas Maughan

text: I'm glad to see thought being put into how we change behaviors of the public.  But, unfortunately, this will not make much difference until we change the VOTING behavior of the public.  We need a concerted national effort led by informed and dedicated representatives who are NOT funded by the corporate energy and war industries.  We need carbon legislation, national health care, high-speed rail systems, alternative energy projects, and the transformation of our factory-farming system to a more local and sustainable system.  We need real representation for all people and true social justice so that all people can see that they have a stake in building a society that is climate friendly and sustainable.  Buying a better refrigerator will not get the job done.
author: Greg McKenzie

text: It doesn't matter if it's real or not, or if you don't care that it's getting colder or hotter; climate change is a problem because it is connected to about every other environmental problems out there. If you care about pollution, deforestation, or protection of the human health in general you would support solutions towards climate change because those solutions would also solve other problems as well. Cleaner air never hurt anybody, burning fossil fuels does. Also, it's not just using fossil fuels, it's using single use products, especially plastic. Not only does it create tons of waste unable to break down for thousands of years, the process of making it causes carbon emissions, causing air pollution and, whether you believe it or not, climate change. It's not some theory. You want proof? Look at history. London smog. Every country that industrialized early went through the problem of air pollution, and now with regulation it has subsided. Just because you don't feel the direct consequences of it doesn't mean that you can brush it off like it's some fairy tale. You can see it in front of your eyes in countries like China and Korea where micro dust is plaguing on the people. Everyone contributes to the problem, so it's everyone's responsibility to contribute to the solution.

text:
What is 'normal climate'? What we just had yesterday? A year ago? 10 years ago? When was it normal enough for you to draw a line and say what normal is, is the way the world was on such and such a date.


I live in an area with 4  seasons, and temps from -40 to +30 ¬∞C. There is no normal at all, there is only a history of what has been. Any extreme temperature doesn't do anything except broaden the range of the known temperature fluctuation. This makes future temperature extremes less extreme than they were. In fact, variation IS NORMAL and if the weather suddenly became exactly the same every day (on an annual comparison basis), that would be ABNORMAL and then we'd have to fret about that, and we'd wish for the 'old days' when every day was a surprise ;)

text:
Did u say Global WARNING? 
There's really no such thing as a "climate denier", nor I would suggest a "climate expert." Climates are always changing randomly, daily, yearly,and historically. There are far too many highly complex disciplines and unpredictable parameters that effect climate, to be an expert or predict future levels, (as all the dubious computer models have failed to do). As a scientist myself (organic chemistry and biochemistry), I deal in empirical data. As such, I 'd say I'm not an expert but a climate "realist". 
I'm not chasing NGO, NASA, or institutional funding to pursue such career, so I dont create a problem, fudge data or propose a solution. To expect "global average" temperature to NOT rise or fall by 1 degree or sea levels by one cm or two over 100years is farcical!! That's assuming we can even measure such parameters accurately or meaningfully. Tide gauges for example, are subject to gravity and land movement etc. 
Earth's temperature varies between ~ -50C and +60C depending on season, altitude, latitude, sunspot activity, atmospheric moisture, undersea volcanoes, ocean dipoles, tectonic plate movement, deforestation, urban island effects etc etc. Moreover, the "average" temperature makes little attempt to consider data error or confidence limits, irregular placement of thermometers and accuracy of past empirical data. What really annoys me is when I see a graph with the Y axis showing a range of 1 to 2 degrees. Any small variation will appear to the novice, as an alarming vertical rise when it would be a virtual straight line if the full range of temperatures being measured are expressed.
author: Gerry De naro

text: Climate Change is a natural phenomenon that has been happening for thousands upon thousands of years. Besides the CO2 produced by man made machines, there are over 7 billion people exhaling CO2 thousands of times per day. There are also billions upon billions of animals that exhaling CO2. There are also natural phenomenons such as volcanoes that release CO2. There is also the fact that CO2 is even the largest greenhouse gas. Water Vapor is. The reason that the condition of the world deteriorates is because of the Second Law of thermodynamics which says, ‚Äúas one goes forward in time, the net entropy (degree of disorder) of any isolated or closed system will always increase (or at least stay the same).‚Äù This means as time increases the conditions of any object or even the earth itself will either remain the same or decrease. It will never improve. For example: If you leave a truck sitting out in a field for several years it will rust and not work anymore. The same thing will happen to the earth which is why inevitably it will be destroyed no matter what we do about it.

text:
Luke M1A1981X M I know this response is late, but...

So, there is a difference between weather and climate. Weather can vary in the short term, whereas climate is a gradual trend. Global warming does not mean that very cold days will just go away immediately and summers will always have days of searing heat. It does mean that those super cold days will gradually happen less and less and winters will grow more mild, and the heat of summer will kick in sooner. 

Also, natural disasters caused by weather will be more common. Look at 2020- California‚Äôs wildfire season has caused two catastrophes, one of which is still going on, Australia had a huge problem with wildfires, the Gulf Coast has been hit with two hurricanes and a tropical storm already this season, with so many storm systems forming that the Weather Service ran out of letters to name them with and had to resort to the Greek alphabet.

Hope this helps, even if you don‚Äôt see it!

text:
Gradual change is often less emotionally impactful than fast-paced change, and many people find problems that don't exist yet or that they can't sense in a primal way less emotionally impactful. A doom and gloom approach can often make people feel pessimistic and hopeless too. Also, many people don't like novelty or making sacrifices, only listen to certain people, and can be more egoistic than altruistic.

Campaign finance reform in the US needs to be tackled. Other forms of electoral reform can help too. Climate change also needs better branding, and we need to adapt in a way that'll be sustainable with aspects of American culture or find ways around them or ways to change them.

text: Personally, my plan is to buy land in new zealand away from the coast. It's an isolated country with a cooler climate. Its sad thinking about the future, but maybe it would help having a plan in place, even if it's small, just so you can try and manage the anxiety. As individuals we can't singlehandedly change the future of the world, we can only try and make our own future a bit more safe. I probably won't have kids unless the future looks like it will change course for the better (which I think it will)

text: I'm not downplaying the potential seriousness of drastic climate change, BUT one thing the video fails to mention after drawing a direct comparison to the ozone "crisis". First, chlorofluorocarbons were scientifically proven to be the direct cause of destruction of ozone when radiation breaks up CFCs causing them to release chlorine atoms that steal an oxygen atom from ozone to form chlorine monoxide. This was not a "scientific consensus", this was an empirically proven scientific _fact_. The fact is climate change is another beast entirely. We cannot prove with empirical data the exact cause-and-effect of carbon emissions on the climate model. Therefore, there is a scientific _consensus_. A consensus isn't fact, it's an agreement on an opinion.There's no data that suggests if all carbon emissions suddenly stop the climate will begin to cool. The climate has fluctuated for millions of years without our help. Is carbon emissions a bad thing for the planet? Absolutely. Pollution of any kind is not a great thing. But facts are facts, and we cannot prove with a high confidence % that X directly causes Y in terms of planetary climate. The scale is too massive, and the effort required on a global, multi-national scale to even make a measurable impact in atmospheric carbon levels is so high and expensive it just isn't feasible. To quote the late, great Tupac Shakur--that's just the way it is.

text: ¬†@Cure¬† Humans don't need meat, let alone red meat, it is merely a tasty and quick source of protein which is sometimes rooted in traditions. India, for example, has been and is a country with a huge amount of vegetarians, other historical societies have been vegetarian too. Red meat in particular has been linked to unhealthy lifestyles but also as one of the most polluting and inefficient food sources. Most cattle eat crops that are grown specifically for them and if we stopped feeding livestock all the crops and food that we do currently, we could feed more than the current world population. I'm not blaming the USA here, Brazil and China are massive contributors to global warming too, the guy was just making a joke about "getting rid of the USA" cause that's a typical international view of the USA.
author: randomthing42

text: ‚Äã¬†@randomthing42¬† - Red Meat is not responsible for the lead to a unhealthy lifestyle. It is the person responsible. Red Meat is, by our understanding, one of the healthiest things you can consume as a human. India is being noted as a large vegetarian country simply due to the lack of meat. They also have one of the highest starvation rates in the world. Poor example to support your claim. In addition, if we stopped feeding livestock all the food and crops that we do currently, and instead feed the people. Well I guess, with your idea, we will all just be eating grass and hay. Because that's literally the primary food source for livestock. I don't think you understand the idea behind multiplying food amount. You get things like grass, that humans simply can't consume and get nutrients from because our bodies can't break the cell walls of grass. Then you feed them to animals that can eat the grass, then proceed to harvest them. It's a rather simple idea. The world will not reduce hunger rates by reducing livestock amount, in fact doing that, will result in the complete opposite. We actually need more livestock than we currently have, in addition to better and faster exporting of said foods. Reduce global warming in other forms, not by removing livestock. It will literally result in even higher starvation rates.

text:
This video is such a joke. Climate change is not due to ordinary people doing ordinary things. Climate change is a result of huge corporations caring about profit over pollution, and countries being unwilling to adopt renewable energy sources for essentially the same reason. It is also a result of renewables being pretty awful to power many of the technologies we use. How do we change this? As for the technological side, we're working on it diligently, but we're not there yet. As for the political side, I don't see a way other than to become best friends with CEOs and presidents, or get the populous to push them to make greener choices. The second one is especially hard if no one cares. And most people couldn't care much less.

But it's ludicrous to pretend that if only people would turn off lights in their homes more, we could stop climate change. Get real.

text: Yes, but Fear and Guilt are also elements of Pathos in persuasive arguments. No matter the method of persuasion, its next to impossible to get people to modify ingrained behavior. But, one place to start, is gather qualitative data from your target group. Gather data on what is top concern about climate change, gather other relevant data from questions, and develop a campaign based on that data. The average person, is not concerned about every shred of scientific research and evidence, their realm of concerns are much smaller typically, attack that realm, if you want to reach them!

text:
I don't buy the argument that fear doesn't drive people. Fear is the only reason Fox news dominates the airwaves and is the primary tactic of Trump and populism in general. 

The difference between the Ozone/CFC crisis and the carbon emission crisis now is that there was unilateral government support to fix the problem back then. Now we have a climate change denier as the head of the free world and a propaganda machine to spin a narrative of confusion and doubt on the topic. 

Also, the aerosol industry was nothing compared to the lobbying power of the big energy players of today.

text: Even if every person, every automobile, and every factory suddenly emitted zero emissions, the earth would still be headed, head first and at full speed, toward total disaster for one major reason: the military produces enough greenhouse gases, by itself, to place the entire globe, with all its inhabitants large and small, in the most immanent danger of extinction.

text: Climate change has already done irreversible damage. Global-Industrial Mass Society was too large, disorganized and unwieldy to coordinate to prevent this from happening. The world economic powers, and global leaders with less power must find a way to coordinate to prevent further damage. We might need to re-organize society if we want to prevent it from happening even more. We also need to avoid a one-leader world government (all attempts to establish that have failed, and will only fail again) as a "solution". It is intrinsically bad.

Because of that, I believe the conversation needs to be addressed to everyone of all ages - particularly towards democratic countries that produce the most CO2 emissions per capita.

text:
Ironically because of American policies and climate change no matter what they do those without melanin won't be able to thrive in a climate changed world according to a Norwegian study by researchers Gine Roll Skj√¶rv√∏, Frode Foss√∏y, and Eivin R√∏skaft  as the climate gets hotter white/Asian birth rates and life expectancy will continue to lower and they will have to migrate north or go into caves the same way their ancestors did 8000 years ago! For those without Eumelanin (Black brown skin) the entire Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region makes their health weaken as the area is susceptible to some of the more severe consequences of global warming, including lethal heat waves, extensive drought and rising sea levels.Researchers at Germany's Max Planck Institute for Chemistry and the Cyprus Institute in Nicosia have found that the region ‚Äì already incredibly hot in the summer ‚Äì could become so warm that "human habitability is compromised." temperatures could reach dangerous levels for human survivability.for caucasians the threshold is 35 degrees centigrade, for people without melanin's protection against UV radiation this only applies for the most able-bodied people. This means that white people with health problems, children and the elderly have a lower threshold for survivability.The clock is already ticking for those without melanin which is why scientists are spending millions trying to develop artificial melanin for those that can afford it.WHY?...Because global warming is melting the polar icecaps and melting the frozen soil beneath. Until recently, permafrost was not a major concern of climate scientists, because, as the name suggests, it was soil that stayed permanently frozen. But Arctic permafrost contains 1.8 trillion tons of carbon, more than twice as much as is currently suspended in the Earth‚Äôs atmosphere. When it thaws and is released, that carbon may evaporate as methane, which is 34 times as powerful a greenhouse-gas warming blanket as carbon dioxide when judged on the timescale of a century; when judged on the timescale of two decades, it is 86 times as powerful. In other words, we have, trapped in Arctic permafrost, twice as much carbon as is currently wrecking the atmosphere of the planet, all of it scheduled to be released at a date that keeps getting moved up, partially in the form of a gas that multiplies its warming power 86 times over.ALL people have melanin, with the exception of albinos - they have genetic mutation that does not allow for melanin synthesis.The difference is the type of melanin produced, mainly eumelanin and pheomelanin. There is also neuromelonin, but this doesn‚Äôt show up in physical appearance.
Eumelanin is what constitutes for brown pigments. Dark hair, brown eyes, tan or black skin. That‚Äôs the expression of eumelanin, and probably the type of melanin you are most familiar with.
Pheomelanin is what constitutes pink pigments. Red hair, light eyes, pasty and red-hued skin is the expression of a higher presence of pheomelanin. This is more common in people of Caucasian descent.Eumelanin has specific advantages as it is the norm for humans. black skin may enhance the body‚Äôs natural immune system and provide better protection against disease than white skin (Mackintosh, 2001). The melanin in dark skin is believed to help enhance the body‚Äôs natural ability to combat pathogens (Nosanchuk and Casadevall, 2006; Mackintosh, 2001; Manning et al, 2003).Eumelanin has also been implicated in the maintenance of calcium homeostasis (mechanism by which the body maintains adequate calcium levels) known to be involved with calcium ion regulation in the inner ear, which may improve hearing (Furuta et al, 1998; Norris et al, 2005; Nosanchuk and Casadevall 2003, 2006; William, 2007).melanin as it relates to hearing has also found that skin pigmentation reduces the effects of noise-induced temporary hearing loss. For example, empirical studies have shown that people with more skin pigmentation suffer significantly less temporary hearing loss than those with pale skin (Barren√§s and Lindgren, 1990; Maurer et al, 1999). In addition to this, melanin offers resistance to heat or cold, as well as resistance to the activity of inorganic antimicrobial compounds (Garcia-Rivera and Casadevall, 2001; Rosas and Casadevall, 1997) thus improving natural overall health. Which is why people believe tanning makes you appear healthier!darkly pigmented skin is at substantially lower risk of developing skin cancer than is fair skin (Agar and Young, 2005). In the U.S., Also some forms of skin cancer are ‚Äú50 times‚Äù higher in Caucasians than in African Americans, and African Americans have a 13-fold lower incidence of melanoma than do Caucasians (Tadokoro et al, 2003). Melanin also acts as a free radical scavenger and has been shown to protect against Cryptococcus neoformans; this is a parasite of the central nervous system (Curie & Casadevall, 1994; Mitchell & Perfect, 1995). Interestingly, it is known that Caucasians suffer from heightened rates of many diseases that affect the central nervous system. For example, Huntington‚Äôs disease, optic neuritis, Parkinson‚Äôs disease, Multiple Sclerosis, PKU (Phenylketonuria), Anencephaly and Spinal bifida (Bates et al, 2002; Okano et al, 1990; Tanner et al, 1996; Nelson et al, 1997; Modi et at, 2001; Kurtzke, 1979; Alan, 2003). While there may not be any ‚Äòdirect‚Äô relationship between melanin levels and these particular neurodegenerative conditions, it should be noted that (eu)melanin is believed to protect folate and folic acid (Jablonski and Chaplin, 2000; Branda and Eaton, 1978). These are essential vitamins that are particularly important for neural tube development in the unborn (Vorobey et al, 2006; Jablonski and Chaplin, 2000). Depleted levels of these vitamins are caused by UV light exposure (Vorobey et al, 2006; Lapunzina, 2006; Branda and Eaton, 1978), which Caucasians are particularly susceptible (Jablonski and Chaplin, 2000). Depleted levels of these vitamins have been linked to a variety of different birth defects including ‚Äòspinal bifida‚Äô and ‚Äòanencephaly‚Äô (brain malformation). Research has also shown that melanin is actually not a sunscreen ,  against UVB radiation but absorbs and utilizes it (Mackintosh, 2001; Hill, 1992; Scheibner et al., 1986).In fact the study of melanin was the basis for breakthroughs in computer science!Lighter skin has less melanin and what is produced is typically found arranged in clusters of melanosomes in keratinocytes, while darker skin has more melanin and the melanosomes are distributed individually in keratinocytes, thus absorbing light more efficiently (Miyamura, 2006).
Caucasian people, while producing overall lower levels of melanin (Tadokoro et al., 2003; Miyamura, 2006), have also been shown to possess higher concentrations of a more deleterious form of melanin known as ‚ÄúPheomelanin.‚Äù The kind of melanin that helps to cause blonde and red hair (blue and green eyes) also increases the potential for cell death! Pheomelanin filters out UV radiation, but it also increases UV harmful effects and causes cell death, particularly when the melanin is the kind found in light hair or skin (Brash et al., 2004; Maresca, 2006). Melanin plays important roles in vision. Norris et al (2005) show that melanin acts like a neutralizing sponge inside cells in the retina to soak up and destroy reactive oxygen species. Reactive oxygen species, or free radicals, which are energized by light, are thought to play a major role in ‚Äúmacular degeneration‚Äù, the leading cause of blindness in people over the age of 60. The disorder is more prevalent among whites than among African-Americans (Evans, 2003; Norris et al, 2005; Klein et al, 1999). The disorder is also found in higher frequencies among people with light eyes than people with dark eyes (Nicolas et al, 2003).Although African Americans (6.6%) were found in a longitudinal study to have slightly higher rates of myopia (near sightedness), not significantly different from white Americans (4.4%), Asians were shown to have the highest prevalence (18.5%), followed by Hispanics (13.2%) (Kleinstein et al, 2005). For hyperopia, whites have the highest prevalences (19.3%), followed by Hispanics (12.7%). Asians were shown to have the lowest prevalence of hyperopia (6.3%) and were not significantly different from African Americans (6.4%).

text:
This is an extremely important video, Vox! Thank you so much for making it happen. I only have two issues with it:

1. It severely glosses over our food choices having a major impact on climate change, specifically how animal agriculture is the leading contributor to greenhouse gas emissions, deforestation, ocean deadzones and many major problems the planet is facing today. I'm very tired of this bias. The science is all there. Adopting a plant-based diet is one of the most environmentally-friendly choices a consumer can make.

2. It focuses mostly on widespread consumer choices. In reality, corporations, governments and high-class citizens contribute exponentially more to climate change than you and I. A lot of consumers' lifestyle choices are negligible and easily offset by corporations and the 1%. Theyre the ones we should focus on... and crack down on the hardest.

text:
We are gradually making ourselves more efficient, and that is good, but it's not enough to tip the scale. Individual competitions among single citizens may be a grassroots motivation, but the real damage comes from our industries, our products, our materials. There needs to be a greater push to ramp up fuel economy, and rid ourselves of dependency on oil. That means, no gasoline, no plastics, and less fresh water consumption. 
I have made a commitment to myself to rid my household of unnecessary plastics. Once a bottle is emptied, I will actively search out eco-friendlier solutions, with better packaging, and less harmful chemicals. It's easy to turn down grocery bags, and plastic razors, disposable cutlery and dishes, and other items that use low grade plastics. I won't use takeout containers unless they're made from recycled fibers. I'm investigating my city's recycling program, and seeing what forms of waste are predominantly making up our landfills. My plan is to get involved with the city council to start asking businesses to invest in biodegradable options for packaging and products to help eliminate waste. Our disposable items are some of the worst designed products imaginable, in terms of material waste to produce them, and the amount of waste involved in throwing them away.
I know people out there think that this is alarmist, and we are putting undue economic pressure on industries to compete for energy conservation and carbon capture, but the way I see it, it's essential to revolutionize our energy sources and infrastructure. It's like having someone argue for the candlestick industry in the age of the incandescent bulb. Why wouldn't we want to upgrade?! A more efficient, cleaner energy source is on the horizon, and it's time we all made the concerted effort to bring that into reality, and start reducing our wasteful tendencies now.

text:
People don‚Äôt think about climate change because it‚Äôs very hard to picture from a human scale. When we hear ‚Äú2 degree increase will be catastrophic‚Äù we think that sounds like nothing because on a human scale, it is. But on a global scale, it‚Äôs so enormous you can‚Äôt picture it correctly. Also terms like ‚Äúglobal warming‚Äù cause most people to picture everything getting hotter and winters going away. And dispel the term whenever it‚Äôs cold. First, climate is not the weather, it will still get cold. Second, global warming means it will get hotter, but not hot enough for a single human to notice, but again, on a global scale, it makes a big difference.

So ‚Äúglobal warming‚Äù and ‚Äúclimate change‚Äù are technically correct terms, but are worded really badly if the goal is to get people to care.

author: Crystal Giddens

text: One of the reasons that it is difficult for modern scientists to quantify the possible extent in global warming is that accurate climatic data extends back, at best, only about a hundred years. Accordingly, it is difficult to determine whether any data indicating global warming is simply a normal variation in a general downtrend, or a normal variation in generalized warming pattern.
author: Crystal Giddens

text: The preceding and substantially longer sequence of alternating glacial and interglacial ages is the Pleistocene Epoch. Because there is nothing to suggest that the Pleistocene has actually ended, certain authorities prefer to extend the Pleistocene up to the present time; this approach tends to ignore humans and their impact, however. The Holocene forms the chronological framework for human history. Archaeologists use it as the time standard against which they trace the development of early civilizations.
author: Crystal Giddens

text:
One of the most important means is carbon-14 dating. Because the age determined by the carbon-14 method may be appreciably different from the true age in certain cases, it is customary to refer to such dates in ‚Äúradiocarbon years.‚Äù These dates, obtained from a variety of deposits, form an important framework for Holocene stratigraphy and chronology.

The limitations of accuracy of radiocarbon age determinations are expressed as ¬± a few tens or hundreds of years. In addition to this calculated error, there also is a question of error due to contamination of the material measured. For instance, an ancient peat may contain some younger roots and thus give a falsely ‚Äúyoung‚Äù age unless it is carefully collected and treated to remove contaminants. Marine shells consist of calcium carbonate (CaCO3), and in certain coastal regions there is upwelling of deep oceanic water that can be 500 to more than 1,000 years old. An ‚Äúage‚Äù from living shells in such an area can suggest that they are already hundreds of years old.

text:
You know, your arrogance will bite you in the ass someday. First lets change the current definition used in this video of Climate change, to actual climate change, not world temperature change. Climate change refers to a climate, a specific area of the world, and it's condition. This definition of climate change is the one we will suppose is correct, which it is, and going by this, I agree climate change is real, the climate of different parts of the world is constantly changing. However, Earth's overall climate has always warmed and cooled, and the 20th century rise in global temperature is within the bounds of natural temperature fluctuations over the past 3,000 years. Although the planet has warmed 1-1.4¬∞F over the 20th century, it is within the +/- 5¬∞F range of the past 3,000 years. A 2003 study by researchers at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics found that "many records reveal that the 20th century is probably not the warmest nor a uniquely extreme climatic period of the last millennium." A 2005 study published in Nature found that "high temperatures - similar to those observed in the twentieth century before 1990 - occurred around AD 1000 to 1100" in the Northern Hemisphere. A 2013 study published in Boreas found that summer temperatures during the Roman Empire and Medieval periods were "consistently higher" than temperatures during the 20th century. According to a 2010 study in the Chinese Science Bulletin, the recent global warming period of the 20th century is the result of a natural 21-year temperature oscillation, and will give way to a "new cool period in the 2030s. 

"I'm referring to people that have died that wouldn't have otherwise... specifically I'm thinking of extreme heatwaves - that have killed thousands - that can be attributed to human-caused global warming."

This point is irrelevant as it has to do with climate change, not world temperature change. Evidence suggests that this was a natural occurrence, and has happened since 1000 B.C. at least.


"Your Ice Age comment (presumably intending the Little Ice Age) is irrelevant... which you'd understand, if you understood this issue. But you don't, so the rational course of action for you is to silently and humbly heed the findings of the climate scientists."

Going by your prior statement as to the comment referring to the ice age I had written, I can conclude that you have some knowledge as to why my statement was "irrelevant" Would you be kind enough to share this?
Simple faculty and logic would conclude that, when coming out of an ice age, the temperature levels would rise as a direct result of the implied ice.

In a previous comment I mentioned that Capitalism is a big issue (if not the main one).. Here's why I think that...

First of all, money is power and people are greedy... The 3% that owns more money than the combined 45% of the world, tries only to maximise their own profit-- all at the expense others.

Secondly-- targeting the consumers to stop the problem..

If you try to convince people to buy  ethically sourced/environmentallly friendly products, it results in them switching to other sellers. 

Here's an example..
Let's say that Sony is super environmentally friendly..

Instead of buying an iPhone, you convince the masses to buy an Xperia, for the good of the environment..

Soon, the people in charge of Sony will find ways of maximising profit through cheaper materials and by cutting wages or by lengthening work hours..
What I'm saying is that positions of power attract the most greedy and immoral people..
I even heard that 1/5 CEOs are psychopaths (I'm not where this is from but I'm sure you'll find it if you look)..

text:
Did u say Global WARNING? 
There's really no such thing as a "climate denier", nor I would suggest a "climate expert." Climates are always changing randomly, daily, yearly,and historically. There are far too many highly complex disciplines and unpredictable parameters that effect climate, to be an expert or predict future levels, (as all the dubious computer models have failed to do). As a scientist myself (organic chemistry and biochemistry), I deal in empirical data. As such, I 'd say I'm not an expert but a climate "realist". 
I'm not chasing NGO, NASA, or institutional funding to pursue such career, so I dont create a problem, fudge data or propose a solution. To expect "global average" temperature to NOT rise or fall by 1 degree or sea levels by one cm or two over 100years is farcical!! That's assuming we can even measure such parameters accurately or meaningfully. Tide gauges for example, are subject to gravity and land movement etc. 
Earth's temperature varies between ~ -50C and +60C depending on season, altitude, latitude, sunspot activity, atmospheric moisture, undersea volcanoes, ocean dipoles, tectonic plate movement, deforestation, urban island effects etc etc. Moreover, the "average" temperature makes little attempt to consider data error or confidence limits, irregular placement of thermometers and accuracy of past empirical data. What really annoys me is when I see a graph with the Y axis showing a range of 1 to 2 degrees. Any small variation will appear to the novice, as an alarming vertical rise when it would be a virtual straight line if the full range of temperatures being measured are expressed.

text:
Sea level changes over relatively recent geologic and human history demonstrate that alarmist claims do not withstand scrutiny. Sea levels rose significantly after the last ice age, fell during the Little Ice Age, and have been rising again since the LIA ended around 1850. In fact, Roman Empire and Medieval port cities are now miles from the Mediterranean, because sea levels actually fell during the Little Ice Age.

During the deepest part of the last ice age, known as the Wisconsin, sea levels were about 400 feet lower than at present. As Earth emerged from the Wisconsin some 18,000 years ago and the massive ice sheets started to melt, sea levels began rising. Rapid sea level rise during the ‚Äúmeltwater pulse phase,‚Äù about 15,000 years ago, was roughly five meters (16 feet) per century ‚Äì but then slowed significantly since the Holocene Climate Optimum, about 8,000 years ago.
author: basket of deplorables

text:
That 400 ppm (of CO2) is actually dangerously low is a fact the alarmists keep avoiding and suppressing. Below 150 ppm, plant-life dies off on a massive scale. Over the Earth‚Äôs history, atmospheric CO2 concentrations have ranged from 180 ppm to 7000 ppm. http://notrickszone.com/2013/05/17/atmospheric-co2-concentrations-at-400-ppm-are-still-dangerously-low-for-life-on-earth/#sthash.L3ATVFrW.dpbs

text:
Those rising oceans created new ports for Greek and Roman naval and trade vessels. But today many of those structures and ruins are inland, out in the open, making them popular tourist destinations. How did that happen? The Little Ice Age once again turned substantial ocean water into ice, lowering sea levels, and leaving former ports stranded. Not enough ice has melted since 1850 to make them harbors again.
The ancient city of Ephesus was an important port city and commercial hub from the Bronze Age to the Minoan Warm period, and continuing through the Roman Empire. An historic map shows its location right on the sea. But today, in modern-day Turkey, Ephesus is 5 km from the Mediterranean. Some historians erroneously claim ‚Äúriver silting‚Äù caused the change, but the real ‚Äúculprit‚Äù was sea level change.
Ruins of the old Roman port Ostia Antica, are extremely well preserved ‚Äì with intact frescoes, maps and plans. Maps from the time show the port located at the mouth of the Tiber River, where it emptied into the Tyrrhenian Sea. The Battle of Ostia in 849, depicted in a painting attributed to Raphael, shows sea level high enough for warships to assemble at the mouth of the Tiber. However, today this modern-day tourist destination is two miles up-river from the mouth of the Tiber. Sea level was significantly higher in the Roman Warm Period than today.

text: An important turning point in British history occurred in 1066, when William the Conqueror defeated King Harold II at the Battle of Hastings. Less well-known is that, when William landed, he occupied an old Roman fort now known as Pevensey Castle, which at the time was located on a small island in a harbor on England‚Äôs south coast. A draw bridge connected it to the mainland. Pevensey is infamous because unfortunate prisoners were thrown into this ‚ÄúSea Gate,‚Äù so that their bodies would be washed away by the tide. Pevensey Castle is now a mile from the coast ‚Äì further proof of a much higher sea level fewer than 1000 years ago.

text:
J-
There is literally no scientific discipline that has nothing to say on the topic of climate.  Because climate is such a complex system intrinsically tied to every aspect of our planetary history everything from astrophysics to biology; geology to zoology has some relevant input into our understanding of climate, its function, and its history.
VeryEvilPettingZoo -
I took a peek at their documents, their arguments and in-house climate model. Their arguments are often just silly and/or ignorant, and their model is both absurdly simplistic and confused. 
J-
Is their model more silly or confused than the ones used by the climate alarmists? The models which have a 100% failure rate in their predictive abilities? Those failed models which they want to use in implementing political and economic policy?
VeryEvilPettingZoo -
Re: "... into the politically motivated and funded climate change 'consensus' crowd's conclusions." I don't know who you're referring to there. Certainly it's not the world's climate scientists, since that would mean that your a conspiratorial delusional ignoramus. 
J-
Throw billions of dollars into proving a conclusion and you will find people to prove that conclusion. Deny money to those who do not agree with the theory and there will be fewer opposing voices. Politics has a lot of power motivation to throw money at global warming, no wait climate change, or whatever new name they come up with next when their latest model proves to be as non-predictive as the previous attempts.
VeryEvilPettingZoo -
Re: "Take a look at the other side, then get back to me." Okay - and now I'm back to you. I've been tracking this issue for decades, from before there even was an IPCC. And by tracking I mean tracking both the actual science, and the endless vomit of denier bullshit. I can't tell you how many times I've had to explain to some mindless denier parrot what their own talking point actually is before I can even begin explaining why it's ridiculous. 
J-
Then how do you square the persistent and repeated model failure? I'm sorry but you can throw all the numbers, PhDs, data, social and political concurrence around that you want - but predictive failure is failure.
author: Joanne H

text:
You do descend into name calling at the first little challenge to your ideas. I thought I was talking to another adult. Consider my guestimation of your age and maturity level downgraded a couple of decades. 

Some of my skepticism, I admit, comes from life experience. I have seen scientific prophets come and go several times in my lifetime, and as prophets go they just weren't very accurate. They spun a good line with numbers and graphs. Each time politicians and enthusiastic supporters would jump on the 'something must be done' bandwagon. Very rarely did their predictions pan out in real world results.

Science is a tool and a scientist is only as good as their real world results. I don't find anything delusional in looking at, or in my case, remembering, the predictions that climate change... enthusiasts were making 10 years ago, comparing them to current real world conditions, and noticing that their predictions have come up short. 

The models are not fine. They will not be fine until their predictions are are outside the margin of error for the data collection - which currently they are not.
https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=9&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=0ahUKEwjp78-K4KnZAhUHWa0KHQyoA-0QFgiKATAI&url=https://www.hoover.org/research/flawed-climate-models&usg=AOvVaw24031OJP-_LD3pOf556oVG
 
Politics. While I do believe politics actually does have a lot to do with the global warming movement, that is a swamp for a whole separate thread.
author: Joanne H

text:
Fear and humiliation? How would that even work? You are some stranger on the web. Why would it even occur to you that you would be able to manipulate my emotional state to that degree? Anyone's? If you Could then they would probably be in need of a twice a week on some professional's couch. I also can't see that a desire to inspire fear and/or humiliate says anything good about your character in general but I can see how that would feed right in to 'believing' that anyone who disagrees with you deserves whatever you spew. I know this to be bad temper, immaturity, poor manners, and poor communication skills - or a combination of all of the above. I have never in my life been moved from my opinion by bad manners and name calling, I suspect that no one ever has been.  

We both have political/economic bias in our opinions of who is a credible outlet for scientific information but I can't see what is supposed to be humiliating or fear inspiring about you calling websites names and hashing over your objections to their political and economic system leanings. Your criticisms of sites seem to lean hard in the political/economics realm rather than actual science rebuttal. I am not convinced of a lack of global warming so much as I am convinced that there is a too much political involvement/corruption/simplification involved with the IPCC, its science, political sponsors, and its recommendations. 

You seem to fall right in line with that as well, in feeling that business or privately funded science should be completely disregarded because of potential funding motives i.e. Scientists can be bought. But you also believe that politically funded science is unquestionably credible--- because politicians are pure of heart? and never have power of profit motive to influence outcome? Or Scientists working on the government payroll are special somehow and can't be bought? I like watching Judith Curry's discussions on climate change, she seems remarkably balanced to me.

Science is weird like this. Everybody can believe a theory. Accept it as fact. But let one piece of data not fit, and the theory is so much trash on the road. Errors in data collection, erratic data collection, falsification of data, collusion to manipulate data sets, and ineffective modeling all remain what they are. All of these problems have very publically plagued the IPCC in the last 10 or 15 years. And yet the political drive is to upturn the world economy in a stampede of fear over what might happen.

What I know is that the IPCC uses a number of models which diverge from eachother radically. While they evaluate some as more probable than others they do not discard the improbable ones because they cannot prove any of them definitively false or definitively more accurate. Though they are consistently lowering their guestimate about what the temperature will do.
author: Joanne H

text:
From a historical perspective, an atmospheric CO2 concentration of 400 ppm is actually almost scraping the bottom of the barrel. Over the Earth‚Äôs history, atmospheric CO2 concentrations have ranged from 180 ppm to 7000 ppm, see Figure 1 below. On that scale we are in fact today barely above the Earth‚Äôs record lows. 
That 400 ppm is actually dangerously low is a fact the alarmists keep avoiding and suppressing. Below 150 ppm, plant-life dies off on a massive scale. The Earth actually came very close to that point many times over the last 2 million years during the ice ages. At the bottom of the last ice age just 20,000 years ago, life on the planet literally teetered on the brink when CO2 fell to a level of just 180 ppm.http://notrickszone.com/2013/05/17/atmospheric-co2-concentrations-at-400-ppm-are-still-dangerously-low-for-life-on-earth/#sthash.L3ATVFrW.dpbs

First of all it's impossible to stop emissions. Worldwide, 18% of energy needed is electrical, another 33% is traffic. Germany is kinda advanced with renewable energies. Of those 18% electrical energy needed they provide around 20% from renewable energies. A famous economist calculated that Germany can possibly cover around 50% of electric power needed from solar and wind energy. The problem is, solar and wind are both weak in winter, so giant storages are needed to provide clean energy in winter. The possible locations to build that storages are just Enough to theoretically cover 50% of the today's electric usage. To stop emission we would want to also turn traffic electric. Traffic is 33% of total energy needed. So with electric traffic 3 times more electric energy is needed than now. And as mentioned even now we need twice of the electric power than is possible.

text: This is hilarious.  People really but into this crap.  Poor poor uniformed people.  Buying new energy efficient appliances literally does nothing for the environment.  I hate to be the one to explain this but there's not a guy shoveling coal that's going to stop shoveling and take a break because you're using less electricity.  Seriously though, the high voltage lines coming to a home has a regulated amount of power passing through those lines.  If you completely discover the power from a house the exact same amount of power is passing through the power line.  The transformer just produces more heat.  The electrical grid has to work this way or there wouldn't be a constant and consistent power which modern electronics require.  Explaining it another way would be  the power coming into a home is kept constant regardless of the power usage of the neighboring homes.  The power does but fluctuate because of the usage of any other used of the power line.  This is regulated by the transformer.  All the but new energy efficient... save the planet stuff it's great a marketing plow to get consumers to buy new stuff.  Energy efficiency does save the homeowner miniscule amounts of money but that's all the good you can do from buying new more energy efficient appliances.  Sorry there a campaign to spread disinformation to the mass markets, but it is capitalism after all.  I told you the truth believe it or not.

I dont think you understand, CO2 DOES NOT trap heat or infrared...¬†

Because the green house affect happens when the infrared radiation is scattered and comes back to earth.. thats why earth kept its ambience and that life could evolve is because it always had standard greenhouse affect that kept it "insulated". You are correct, but you have totally misunderstood.¬†

The sun's visible wavelengths of radiation pass easily through the atmosphere and reach Earth. Approximately 51% of this sunlight is absorbed at Earth's surface by the land, water, and vegetation. Some of this energy is emitted back from the Earth's surface in the form of infrared radiation.




"Water vapor, carbon dioxide, methane, and other trace gases in Earth's atmosphere absorb the longer wavelengths of outgoing infrared radiation from Earth's surface. These gases then emit the infrared radiation in all directions, both outward toward space and downward toward Earth. This process creates a second source of radiation to warm to surface ‚Äì visible radiation from the sun and infrared radiation from the atmosphere ‚Äì which causes Earth to be warmer than it otherwise would be. This process is known as the natural greenhouse effect and keeps Earth's average global temperature at approximately 15¬∞C (59¬∞F). If the concentration of greenhouse gases increases, then more infrared radiation will be absorbed and emitted back toward Earth's surface, creating an enhanced or amplified greenhouse effect."

text: VeryEvilPettingZoo This is hilarious.  People really buy into this crap.  Poor poor uniformed people.  Buying new energy efficient appliances literally does nothing for the environment.  I hate to be the one to explain this but there's not a guy shoveling coal that's going to stop shoveling and take a break because you're using less electricity.  Seriously though, the high voltage lines coming to a home has a regulated amount of power passing through those lines.  If you completely disconnect the load of a house the exact same amount of power is passing through the power line.  The transformer just produces more heat.  The electrical grid has to work this way or there wouldn't be constant and consistent power which modern electronics require.  Explaining it another way would be  the power coming into a home is kept constant regardless of the power usage of the neighboring homes.  The power does but fluctuate because of the usage of lack of usage of any other consumer of the power line.  This is regulated by the transformer.  All the buy new energy efficient... save the planet stuff is just a marketing ploy to get consumers to buy new stuff.  Energy efficiency does save the homeowner miniscule amounts of money but that's all the good you can do from buying new more energy efficient appliances.  Sorry there a campaign to spread disinformation to the mass markets, but it is capitalism after all.  I told you the truth believe it or not.  If you want to believe there's a guy at the power station turning back a dial because you turned all your lights off go ahead.  Or you can find out yourself. Get a laser thermometer it better yet an infrared camera and look at the temperature of the transformer nearest to your home.  Then flip the master switch to your home and watch what happens to the temperature of the transformer.  Truth rules.

text: I think a big problem is the scale as it relates to cost and benefits. No one individual, company, organisation, or even nation can do enough to make an appreciable difference to climate change. That means that making changes means sacrificing profits, competitiveness or standard of living for no gain. The problem can only be solved by everyone doing the right thing, but as long as not everyone is doing it, those that are will be disadvantaged compared to those that aren't. Nobody on the macros scale wants to make the first move because addressing climate change only penalises early adopters, with no tangible reward or payoff. Nobody on the micro scale wants to do anything because the results are so insignificant - what's the point of buying that expensive high efficiency washing machine to save a couple tons a year when the factory down the road is pumping out that much every second? As with many things, climate action require huge participation at every level of society to be effective, and either the benefits will be experienced by everyone regardless of participation, or they will not occur at all. That means there is no reason for individual entities to participate beyond altruism, unless forced to or coerced by legislation or artificial economies like carbon trading/taxation.
