This is not a "phase" happening for a "while" this is rapid accelerating warming, that corresponds to rapid accelerating CO2 emissions from growing industry and the destruction of forests, and emissions of other GHG's from farming for example. 

These phases also often have astronomical or geochemical causes, this warming of ours does not, it is due 100% to human activity and corresponds to Human emissions.
author: Fandom guy

text:
¬†@John Peric¬†  Uh no, no true at all, this is the fastest warming has ever occurred and it's accelerating. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=62w-OFabBh0 )     Yes, because the past 5 million years has been a cooling trend, one that was un-interrupted until the Industrial Revolution and beyond.  

Uh, no. Before you argue about climate change and climate history maybe you should know a thing or two about it.   Start here: https://www.skepticalscience.com/
author: Fandom guy

text: ¬†@John Peric¬† Uh no, no it wasn't Solar luminosity follows 11 year cycles.  This is a constant warming. Before the effect of human activity (which began significantly at the industrial revolution) we were slowly, slowly, entering an Ice-Age.  Temperatures dipping.    Also I thought you were arguing for it to be natural?
author: Fandom guy

text:
¬†@John Peric¬†  " also, no human effects didn't become even remotely significant until the late 1800s, and especially after the 1940s. Again, you don't know your history." 

Yeah. Industrial revolution and the acceleration of climate change via the growth of industrial societies worldwide.
author: Fandom guy

text:
‚Äã¬†@John Peric¬†  "also, no I'm not arguing for it being natural, I literally said multiple times that humans have been playing most if not all the role since the 1950s ."

Well, even before that.  The Industrial revolution marked our biggest impact. 


Then, what are you arguing for?  That the climate will one day go back to normal? Of course, but that's only hundreds of thousands if not at least 1-2 Millenia after Humans have gone extinct or stopped (likely due to extinction) .   The damage we are doing to Earth's climate system will take incredibly long deep, timescales to undo.  As with any mass extinction causing cataclysm. 

Yes, life will live on.  Studies suggest the coming mass extinction will be similar to the "end permian"  famously called the "Great Dying" extinction that occurred 252 millennia ago when 93% of all life was eradicated, the most of any.   As you can see, there is life right now.   Life bounces back, just... not the life we'll remember.   And the fact is, the percent that survive mass extinctions tends to be super-hardy, tiny organisms, as in,  not creatures like.... Us.   

Who knows what kind of alien-looking creature will dig up our fossils 252 million years from now. 

( some cool imaginations: 

https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcR121UvwafHW_pEjhdUuhKkIj7NR7d-GpEF0ySlZYE1joSyzovg 

 https://pixel.nymag.com/imgs/daily/intelligencer/2017/07/06/magazine/07-climate-change-feature-lede.w512.h600.2x.jpg

 https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcTMEkY5nylCYqQOCKR9v8Fi9-yHP8WTz_SHKCeraGU0ryxrztsh  

It's the end of the world as we know it~ and I feel fine~ I've grown to accept that there is no hope for humanity to change it's ways.)
 
     Only it most likely won't do so willingly (seeing as how special the evolution of sapient life was), and it probably won't ponder it as we have.  It's a rock, not food.    

Though, there are guesses as to what life might look like in this period: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nhW20TJammg    Speculative evolution is a fun topic.
author: Fandom guy

text: ¬†@George Orwell¬† Radio is not a direct cause of climate change in it of itself.   But it's invention and manufacture is only possible due to fossil fuel energy sources, so... yes?  We should? We won't.  Tech is too good, and the short term is all we know.  We'll invent ourselves to death as is likely the fate of all "intelligent species"  like us in the universe.  All alone.  The only alternative being a space faring race that needs to keep colonizing planets until it too runs out of resources or is poisoned by their actions.
author: Fandom guy

text: ¬†@John Peric¬†  It is constant acceleration, yes.   Uh no, in the 1940s the temperature did not drop rapidly, they dropped a bit and stabilized (with blips) a bit due to the effect of Acid Sulfate aerosol pollutants in the atmosphere, that is, smog clouds, blocking out the sun.  Once air quality was improved by regulation in the 1970s the masked Global warming reappeared on global temperature charts as the sun could shine down on us freely.   Temperatures have not rapidly decreased at all at any time.   They are only rapidly increasing, give or take a few effects like, maybe a volcano blew up somewhere, with ash blocking out a tiny percentage of light for a few years before settling.
author: Fandom guy

text:
¬†@John Peric¬†  Uh no,  the 1600s was the 17th century, the time of earnest colonization, several wars, and the birth of science.   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/17th_century 

I did make a mistake, however.  Industrial revolution is about 1760 to 1840. 

  About 1910 is when the slow global cooling trend leading to the upcoming ice age 10,000 years from now (this event has been cancelled according to recent studies)  was officially reversed by our actions in the global temp average.
author: Fandom guy

text:
¬†@John Peric¬†   Uh no, it doesn't.  At the very least, we don't measure any of that.  Again, Solar Irradiance/radiation/ SUNLIGHT bro,  remains in a constant 11 year cycle, if not dimming in the long term as scientists predict a new minimum.  Yet temperatures are shooting up at an ever accelerating rate while our current stage in the 11 year cycle is towards dimming. 

https://static.skepticalscience.com/pics/TvsTSI.png

Those graphs do not correlate with solar activity.
author: Fandom guy

text:
¬†@John Peric¬† "Sunspots, which appear as dark patches on the solar surface, form where the sun's magnetic field is unusually strong, and the number of sunspots waxes and wanes in a cycle that lasts about 11 years, fueled by fluctuations in the sun's magnetic field.


But during the late 17th century, the sun's spots all but disappeared. This episode corresponded with a period of exceptional cold in parts of the world, which scientists have explained as being connected to the changes in solar activity.   


Sunspot activity was high in 2014 and has been dipping ever since, as the sun moves toward the low end of its 11-year cycle, known as the solar minimum, NASA reported in June 2017"
author: Fandom guy

text:
‚Äã¬†@John Peric¬† 1. The climate is getting warmer at an ever accelerating rate.  Did you watch this?: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=62w-OFabBh0

Your have not convinced me of that.  No disinformation. 

This graph accounts for natural variability and other factors.  https://static.skepticalscience.com/pics/FigFAQ5_1-1_smaller.png 

The dominant factor in Earth Surface Temperatures as measured, is the Anthro-pogenic factor. Anthro-Humans.

2. Uh, no, none of that is happening. I don't even get where it's coming from. https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/co2-levels-rise-climate-change-global-warming-fossil-fuels-met-office-a8744911.html

   CO2 emissions are only rising exponentially, emissions are 55% higher than they were in 1990.  5 times 1950 and 1 time 1980 when global warming science was confirmed.  

https://www.pbl.nl/sites/default/files/cms/publicaties/pbl-2018-trends-in-global-co2-and-total-greenhouse-gas-emissons-2018-report_3125.pdf

https://www.co2.earth/co2-acceleration
 
it doesn't help that, sadly,  feedbacks are now kicking in (keep in mind due to a "lag" in effects, today's climate events do not reflect current CO2 levels) , such as the warming climate making forest fires and bark beetle attacks more common, turning forests into net carbon emitters as they burn and decompose .  and the permafrost melts releasing CO2 and the more powerful Methane. Of which farms still emit much of.   And other feedbacks: https://www.unenvironment.org/news-and-stories/story/taller-plants-warming-arctic-could-speed-climate-change

CO2 targets are not being reached: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/12/07/climate/world-emissions-paris-goals-not-on-track.html  and a rise in right-wing "pro-economy" ideals and nationalism may destroy any liberal progress on the matter.   Right wing US president Donald Trump already fights to deregulate and undo climate progress. 

And even IF Carbon was constrained, 77% of all energy would still come from Fossil Fuels. 

i am one of little faith.   

Plant CO2 absorption rates will likely drop again, the heat forces plants to close their stomata for longer to prevent moisture loss. 

And one must remember that projections tend to end at 2100. 

The Great dying is being recreated ( https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/dec/06/global-warming-extinction-report-the-great-dying ) it was caused by a massive disruption to the carbon cycle via extreme hyper-volcanism and the ignition of internal coal and methane deposits as a result.  (https://skepticalscience.com/Lee-commentary-on-Burgess-et-al-PNAS-Permian-Dating.html) 

Likely forming the Siberian traps which to this day records for us the largest eruptions in geological history. 

Estimates suggest we are increasing CO2 levels 100 times faster than the Great Dying.    By 2250 judging by current CO2 release rates (which we are surpassing) it is predicted Earth will be in Triassic period type conditions.  Back then it was Too hot for Mammals. Mass desertification, iceless (higher sea levels, duh), with wetlands near the coasts.  https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/jp33gx/climate-change-triassic-carbon-dioxide-emissions-global-warming

Though it's hard to compare, the sun was much dimmer 250 million years ago, our future will likely be *worse*.   

I have little faith in CO2 absorbing tech, most such solutions either fall short when their net effect is taken (such as manufacture or powering) or have other consequence.

And ultimately the damage that has ALREADY been done is irreversable on human timescales. 
 
"Positive feedbacks were already occurring at less than 1¬∞C of warming. Many carbon sinks are on the verge of becoming or have already become carbon sources.   (https://psmag.com/environment/droughts-are-turning-the-amazon-into-a-carbon-source)  (https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2019/national/gone-in-a-generation/forest-climate-change.html)     As we race toward a nightmarish future with no realistic way to stop, we leave behind a ‚Äúforever legacy‚Äù that will haunt mankind for the rest of eternity."  (metaphorically speaking, humanity will not last into eternity)  (https://e360.yale.edu/features/taking-the-long-view-the-forever-legacy-of-climate-change)  

CO2 is also not the main problem.  There are other greenhouse gases we are emitting.   

And anyways, CO2 is not the only existential threat humanity has, Overpopulation, Deforestation and animal equivalent Defaunation, biodiversity erasure due to human expansion, Plastic production, pollution.  These and others are still very serious threats that rival climate change and make the sixth extinction more certain. 
 
People are already noting the incredibly loss in biodiversity that has occurred in the past decades.   Flying insects are vanishing https://www.washingtonpost.com/science/2018/10/15/hyperalarming-study-shows-massive-insect-loss/ 
https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/27/magazine/insect-apocalypse.html

Roads and other human infrastructure are dividing and destroying animal habitat reducing populations significantly.   https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/dec/15/new-map-reveals-shattering-effect-of-roads-on-nature 

https://www.nwf.org/Educational-Resources/Wildlife-Guide/Threats-to-Wildlife/Habitat-Loss

The Anthropocene age is a world unrecognizable to nature. Completely alien, dominated by a "superpredator" (official term) a single freak of nature species rapidly evolved from a freak environment, as an evolutionary dead end.  

(https://www.theguardian.com/science/2004/dec/29/evolution.science )

   A world transformed, a world dying. Nothing like this has happened since the first photosynthetic appeared and destroyed earth with Oxygen in the early days of life.   And Civilization is at fault, it consumes endlessly. And everyone wants it, Worldwide.   It requires infinite resources from a finite planet. It is inherently unsustainable.   It's it or us.   And that is why I lack hope.  Because Civilization is great!   It saves lives, it entertains.  It tastes great and glitters. 

So, It's the end of the world as we know it~  And I feel fine~ (this song sums up my view pretty well) 

(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jVmB3lRjCmc )

I know this conversation is just about climate change, but I decided to add those other threats to help you understand my viewpoint. 

This blog can help too:  https://collapseofindustrialcivilization.com/

text: Personally reducing energy consumption does nothing to reduce emissions. Every power plant is rated at a certain out put and produces that out put regardless of consumer consumption. Any excess power that is produced is then shunted into the earth at a remote location. Power grid sharing has reduced this problem somewhat but there are lakes all over North America (presumably the world but I only know of American and Canadian ones for a fact) that have hundreds of thousands of unused energy poured into them every year. If utilities came up with a storage method for all this excess it would do more to accomplish carbon neutrality than most people unplugging the and dishwashers to reduce phantom consumption.

text:
If you became a vegan and changed your lifestyle dramatically to use less energy, and buy an electric car, you aren't even making a dent in the problem of climate change. it doesn't matter what you do personally to reduce your impact. The issue is much greater than you personally. Even if you could convince half of all people to do all of that, it would barely affect the issue. The key is to find a renewable alternative to fossil energy that is cheaper and easier to use.
If you want to really make a difference when it comes to global warming, yes, reduce your personally impact as much as you're comfortable with, but the real impact will be either becoming a scientist or engineer directly involved in new energy technologies or to at least donate to these causes if you can find a way to.

text:
The fatal flaw with this video is the fact that Vox doesn't state how much of a degree humans are changing the climate. They are not precise with their statements. Yes, the climate is changing, but it is definitely not heading in a catastrophic direction at all. The earth has
 experienced countless periods of warming and cooling, and it is a shame that the leftist media are trying to persuade people about a problem that no well-educated person takes seriously. 

     To give 
historical evidence, in the Roman times, the climate was even warmer than it is today (then it gradually cooled down), and it was at least as hot towards the end of the dark ages. Up until now, it is concluded 
that global warming is not happening to the magnitude that Bill Nye and 
Neil deGrasse Tyson says it is. We are still technically in an ice age 
(known as the Pleistocene Ice age, that has been going on since 440,000BC) and the glaciers are still around eroding the landscape. Before this period, the ice caps were nonexistent. (According to Paleontologists)  


     Furthermore, the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere (since the 1850s) 
has been shown to not be correlated to the average temperature of 
earth's climate. And it was only a few decades ago that people actually 
started to take into account that the earth is warming up. The earth's 
temperature only increases 1.5C every century, not identical to the 
figures that professional organizations warned us about. Not only is the
 data confirming global warming not taken with serious intent, but it 
has been confirmed that the climate change researchers tampered with the
 data, a fraud move that makes their rationale appear much less 
attractive.

     If you told me climate change is real, I would 
ask, "How much of that climate change is done by humans?" or "Under 
which studies confirmed this to be true?". Not a single global warming 
researcher can verify these questions without ambiguity nor claim that the 
evidence is undeniable.

text:
+Chicken Of the Cave

"Until I start seeing actual evidence of this then I won't believe it's true."

You wouldn't believe it was true, even if you were given evidence. That's how denialism works:

"It is, however, important not to confuse denialism with genuine scepticism, which is essential for scientific progress. Sceptics are willing to change their minds when confronted with new evidence; deniers are not."
http://www.bmj.com/content/341/bmj.c6950.full



"First it was global warming, and then the earth wasn't actually warming so now its climate change."

You fell for an internet myth. potholer54 debunked this myth of your's in his video:
"26 -- Science vs. the Feelies" from 12:54 - 14:06

The term "climate change" goes back to before the 1990s. What do you think the "CC" in "IPCC" stands for? The use of the term "climate change" has nothing to do with some evasion by scientists. Instead, "climate change" refers to a broader category of phenomena, that includes global warming. So global warming is a type of climate change, just like canines are a type of mammal. And just like biologists can use terms like "canine" and "mammal" without it being a conspiracy, climate scientists can use terms like "climate change" and "global warming" without it being a conspiracy. This is all easily researchable.

"Polluted Discourse: Communication and Myths in a Climate of Denial
[...]
Our results indicate that ‚Äúclimate change‚Äù has been used more often than global warming in the scientific literature and continues to be the more prevalent term in recent years. There also appears to be no relationship between the greater use of the term ‚Äúglobal warming‚Äù (relative to climate change ) and higher temperatures. [...] Our analysis therefore leads us to conclude that the claim that the term global warming was abandoned in favor of the term climate change, in response to stalling temperature, is baseless."
https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-20161-0_3



"The climate does in fact change. Everyday actually. Hotter and colder"

Weather is not climate.



"Water temperatures aren't rising though."

Nonsense.

Surface warming / ocean warming: 
"A reassessment of temperature variations and trends from global reanalyses and monthly surface climatological datasets"
"Estimating changes in global temperature since the pre-industrial period"
"Possible artifacts of data biases in the recent global surface warming hiatus"
"Assessing the impact of satellite-based observations in sea surface temperature trends"

Ocean warming: 
‚ÄúAssessing recent warming using instrumentally homogeneous sea surface temperature records‚Äù
"Tracking ocean heat uptake during the surface warming hiatus"
"A review of global ocean temperature observations: Implications for ocean heat content estimates and climate change"
"Unabated planetary warming and its ocean structure since 2006"
http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg1/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf ["Ocean warming dominates the increase in energy stored in the climate system, accounting for more than 90% of the energy accumulated between 1971 and 2010 (high confidence).[...] On a global scale, the ocean warming is largest near the surface, and the upper 75 m warmed by 0.11 [0.09 to 0.13] ¬∞C per decade over the period 1971 to 2010."]

I've lived on the beach for many years. I go into the ocean just about everyday. I can tell you that the ocean level has not risen. There's a giant wooden post that sits right in the edge of the water. The water always stays right at the edge of it at high tide for as long as I can remember

author: Atomsk's Sanakan

text:
+Atomsk's Sanakan

Okay, I read them over. Really the only bit of information you gave me was the last link. And even with that it didn't show very promising information. The chart had started at around 1850. In fact, I went and researched a while more for charts and information about global temperature history. Yet all the charts seem to start at around the 1800's. Why wouldn't they show information from long before the industrial revolution to emphasize the fact that that is in fact what is causing this? But if you look back at records from long before 1850, they'll show that the earth has constantly undergone time periods of extreme heat and extreme cold. And that was before the industrial revolution. So why would this be any different? I believe we are blaming ourselves for something that is natural to our planet.

It is promising information, I will give you that. But charts are dangerous because there are many ways to "manipulate" data on them.

No, Sir, you are a self-interested and self-righteous a-hole who has oversold his absolutely shitty dissertation based on lazy single-disciplinary science that is the modern equivalent of the plumb pudding model of the atom. text: Don't think about it just do the simple math. Earth SRF (Solar Radiative Forcing) is now 5w/m2. It was 4w/m2. That's a rise of 25% from Water vapour increase 11%, Co2 increase 75%, Methane 150%. These are the main gasses that warm the earth. Without them the earth would be a frozen ice ball. To much and you get a planet like Venus, 600'c all due to a Co2 atmosphere. The earth temperature increases by 7.5'c for every 1w/m2 increase in SRF. Its the only number we need to know. SRF is (5w/m2) 15. The minus 15 is because the earth is further from the sun than Venus. Venus is used as the Zero point as this was the planet chosen to conduct experiments on atmospheric forcing of a planets temperature. Venus SRF is 80w/m2. (80x7'5) +/ SWRI) = 600'c Exactly correct. Earth SRF was 4w/m2 (4x7.5) -15 = 15'c Again exactly correct. Earth SRF is now 5w/m2 (5x7'5) -15 = 22.5'c. The earth must now break¬†the laws of physics, chemistry and thermo dynamics¬†for it not to warm by 7.5'c over the next 40 years.

text:
3:35 - stop blabbing about CO2- it's not to blame!! The problem is POTENCY not VOLUME.

CH4 (Methane) is doing 17x more¬†damage than¬†CO2... Though it only makes up ~15% of air pollutants by VOLUME, it warms the atmosphere 85x more than CO2 (~76% of volume). Luckily, Methane decays after¬†a decade or so into CO2. Human activity is responsible for 65% of global CH4 emissions, and our main contributor is LIVESTOCK. 

N2O (Nitrous Oxide) is doing 27x more damage than CO2... Though it¬†makes up only ~7% of GHG volume, it warms the atmosphere 298x more than CO2 (i.e. GWP = 298), and it doesn't degrade! Human activity is responsible for 38% of global N2O emissions and our main contributor is FERTILIZER. 

*Let's not forget that agriculture covers 40% of the Earth and compliments forest destruction, which are our planet's air filters.

Reduce your meat and dairy intake - save your health, your wallet, and your world!

text:
I'm not a vegetarian, but drastically reduced my¬†meat & dairy¬†consumption for health and environmental reasons. 

Anyways, please research:

- "GHG flow chart" - GHG atmospheric volume proportionality
- "GWP chart" (Global Warming Potential) - GHG warming potencies¬†
- "anthropogenic climate change" - human involvement in GHG production
- "causes of deforestation" - reasons of deforestation
- "attribution of climate change" - a general summary

The main agencies providing data are the IPCC (international), EPA (USA), and EEA (Europe). 

They pretty much all agree; however, the EPA calculates GHG's on a 100 year horizon, despite certain GHG's, like methane,¬†causing the majority of their warming effects in a shorter term.
author: aeopmusic

text:
VeryEvilPettingZoo 

1.) GWP #: CH4 oxidizes into CO2 after 12.4 years according to the AR5, hence the 20 year GWP (~85) is higher than CH4's 100 year GWP (28~36). We agree on this‚Ä¶

2.) GHG VOLUME (%): The atmospheric GHG proportionality of CO2 is 76% and for CH4 it is 16% (average highs). Hence, there is 4.75x more CO2 molecules in the atmosphere as CH4. We agreed here also‚Ä¶

3.) GHG VOLUME (PPM): I found that these percent ratios are perhaps misleading, so I tried parts-per notation. CO2 is 400ppm and CH4 is 1.8ppm‚Ä¶ This suggests there is ~222x more CO2 in the atmosphere than CH4. Hence the "4.75" we BOTH calculated is perhaps useless. 

3.) CALCULATION
**Via ppm volume: 85 / 222 = 0.38 (20 yr CH4 GWP / CO2 to CH4 GHG volume ratio); Total Atmospheric (aka "TA") CH4 is 0.38x less impactful than TA CO2 in a 20 year horizon. You mentioned at the end of your message the IPCC AR5 pg. 14 gave a figure indicating CH4's TA warming effect to be half that of CO2, which seems to confirm this result. **

Via % volume (incorrect?): 85 / 4.75 = 17.89 (20 yr CH4 GWP divided by CO2 to CH4 volume % ratio); TA CH4 is 17.89x more responsible than TA CO2 in a 20 year horizon. I don't know why you divided 36/85 (i.e. 20 yr CH4 GWP / 100 yr)‚Ä¶ In combining GHG volume with the GWP on a 20 year horizon, we don't care about the 100 yr CH4 GWP figure.

TWO QUESTIONS:
‚Ä¢ computing for anthropogenic contribution vs. natural (e.g. 97% of TA CO2 is nature made, methane is lower?)
‚Ä¢ Any comment on Nitrous Oxide?

text:
8% drop in energy use seems like a LOT for just behavioral change, I'm dubious that can be sustainably achieved. People like warm, lit houses and cold beer. 

8% is more than OPower has achieved, and they've got a huge dataset, and serious subject matter expertise in effecting behavior. 

This video feeds the false belief that people can game their energy bills by changing how they behave without giving up anything, which has proven false over and over again. This sets people up for failure, which leads to disbelief and quitting all efforts. These virtue signalling videos are well intentioned but they actually do more harm than good.

The way to sustainably save major energy is fix performance problems in poorly performing homes. Full stop. 


I don't believe 19% can be achieved in homes with kids, I suspect cherry picking. I don't believe any of these numbers, and I see no link provided to the study.

text:
Sometimes in my fantastical thinking, I wonder if just not letting those who aren't serious about aggressively tackling climate change and maybe other environmental problems too have a say and not letting them have power because they only get in the way. I know it may not be the best way or reality, but forcing out people of power who get in the way like this and who are beholden to greedy, antisocial massive corporations who are part of the problem is an interesting thought.

These new people in power would boldly and aggressively change stuff like:
-finding alternatives to plastic which are biodegradable
-have mandatory recycling like Germany does and recycle as much or more than Sweden does
-set a concrete plan to convert all energy to renewable and fund more research into more forms of it
-create carbon taxes and phase out dirty fuel and maybe eventually make it illegal somehow
-change us from having way less disposable products to the opposite
-reduce human population humanely (not kill people)
-protect and expand fresh water reserves
-make us into a sustainable farming nation (USA)

A lot of this is idealistic, but there's a place for it. I hope this would set an example to the rest of the world and would cause revolutions around the globe.

text: ¬†@Bvgger 0ff pls¬† Oatmeal doesn't have that much protein. It has about 3 grams per 100g. Spaghetti has protein in it and it has carbs. That being said, you only need 0.8 grams of protein per kilo of your body weight. If you weigh 180lbs, youd need 66 grams of protein per day. This can easily be achieved by eating plant based foods. If you have two sandwiches, that's 16 grams of protein just from the bread. There are many plant based foods rich and protein, so it's kinda ignorant to say you can only get sufficient amounts from meat. Meat is a great source of protein, but not that great for your colon or heart.
author: de sp

text:
‚Äã¬†@de sp¬† lol, my bad, I was referring to dry oats which contain 11g of protein per 100g, meanwile spaghetti only contains 6g and far less fibre.
Correction: you only need 0.8g of protein per kilo to maintain your bodyweight on a lifestyle of low to moderate physical activity. If you live an active lifestyle, are an athlete (pro or amateur), crossfitter, bodybuilder, labourer, soldier, fireman, fitness enthusiast, whatever, your protein demands are going to be much higher along with your caloric needs, potentially 1.5g or higher per kilo. To suggest that one size fits all is ignorant. 
There are indeed plant based foods high in protein. But I'm sure none of them are as cheap and calorie-efficient as meat. If you can tell me a plant based food that contains 25g of protein per 100g for less than 280 calories (no overpriced supplements), I'll be impressed. If you can give me a plant-based source of protein that meets the above criteria and is as affordable as meat, I'll turn vegan right now. But even then, plant  based foods won't contain as many omega 3s b12s, iron, zinc, creatine etc.
Meat has drawbacks, so do chickpeas, kale, soy, brazil nuts, peanuts, grains and other vegan staples. I don't see your point. At the end of the day, meat is the cheapest most efficient and nutritionally dense source of protein and there is no reason to supplement it for vegan 'alternatives' from a health perspective.
author: Bvgger 0ff pls

text: Veganism is indeed better for the environment. That, however, is not a strong enough argument to turn society vegan
author: Bvgger 0ff pls

text:
¬†@Bvgger 0ff pls¬† I don't see that your point against supplements is though. Many body builders take protein supplements because they can't get it all from meat. Whey protein for example is a great way to add protein to your diet. And I don't get what your point is in the first place. I'm just naming random plant based foods, whether they be healthy or not, they have protein in them, which is great for the average person, and proves that you can be healthy without meat and or animal products. I'm not a vegetarian or vegan, but I can see that veganism isn't depriving you of protein. Chickpeas are also a great source of protein, being 19% protein by weight (close to chickens 22%) and very high in fibre, iron, and vitamin B-6. 

Also meat prices vary depending where you live. In Canada it's pretty expensive and far cheaper to eat beans and such.
author: de sp

text: ¬†@Bvgger 0ff pls¬† yes it is a strong reason for people to be vegan. Eating meat is unsustainable because it consumes lots of water and land. Lots of land and water is used to grow crops that go to feed cows and chickens, but not humans. It's worth noting that cows also release a lot of methane, which is a greenhouse gas stronger than CO2 which contributes to climate change. Climate change is becoming a huge issue facing society and makes veganism a good solution to this problem.
author: de sp

text:
¬†@de sp¬† I said meat is a primary source of protein, you said it isn't. You said you can get all your protein from plant based sources, I explained why that is far from ideal. You said you only need a certain amount of protein, I explained why that isn't true. Not sure what you're confused about.
Pretty much every foodstuff contains protein. How much protein they contain in relation to other macronutrients is a whole other consideration.
As for supplements, they exist for one purpose, to contain as much protein as possible for as few calories as possible and to be as palatable as possible, hence why bodybuilders use them. I.e. people who can't be bothered to get protein from other sources. They don't contain the micronutrients that can be found in whole foods, yet they often cost more. What's so great about that?
As I said previously, one size doesn't fit all. What if someone is on a 2500 calorie diet but requires 180g of protein a day to support their level of physical activity? Are you suggesting they rely on supplements Mr Healthy? If we're talking about normal 9-5 normies who don't partake in strenuous physical activity, a vegan diet is more realistic. Not everyone is a 9-5 office working normie though. Again, veganism is far from ideal. Meat is great. A cheap source of protein and a nutritional power-house. Whey and Soy-isolate? Not so much lol. Try telling the average gym-goer or marine that they should go vegan
author: Bvgger 0ff pls

We can find a better solution to the problem of climate change then just keep pushing conservation. That idea is a really impractical one and has got to go.

2. If one country, say the US, successfully stops all energy consumption and artificial CO‚ÇÇ emission, other countries would be able to run circles around them technologically and take advantage of them.

3. Technology relying on energy consumption, such as developing and distributing medicines can greatly improve the quality of human life.

4. As technology increases so does our ability to solve this problem by looking into creative solutions (for instance doing more research into crispr to genetically modify cyanobacteria to turn CO‚ÇÇ into O‚ÇÇ at a faster rate, reversing the process of global warming )

text: Climate is bad for everything. Maybe in the short term, there will be a longer growing season for some countries. However, glaciers and other ice forms will melt and increase sea levels globally, causing a rise of 1-4 feet of water by the year 2100.  The warming of the Earth will lead to more wildfires, less precipitation, which increases particulate matter in the air, causing poor air quality resulting in respiratory and other illnesses. Additionally, increasing temperature put people at risk for of an occurrence insect and foodborne illness. Lastly, climate change will cause an increase in natural disasters putting more mental and physical stress on human populations. Not to mention ocean acidification and less available oxygen on Earth.

text:
Donny Donadio you're not actually learning. Their figures are highly inflated. Animal agriculture is a factor in climate change, but not the #1 factor by a long shot. 

Don't get me wrong, animal agriculture has greatly increased animal populations; thereby increasing their production of GHGs. These animals use up land that may have once been a forest and they require more land to feed them. Now certain animals are worse than others, especially cows. Per 1kg of meat, a cow requires 20 times more area of land compared to a chicken (both for food and physical space combines) and they produce far more GHGs per kg than any other animal. We don't have to go vegan, we just need to reduce meat consumption, especially beef.

text:
is there like an anti-agriculture group trying to spam vox or something. As you can see here: https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/sources-greenhouse-gas-emissions, Electricity and Transportation are much larger sources of greenhouse gas emissions than agriculture, though -- as pointed out by all these trolls -- agriculture is still a large source.

However, greenhouse gas emissions coming from transportation and electricity are far easier to target since we already have enough technology to convert all of our energy grid and transportation sources to clean energy if we just invested in these technologies. Restructuring our agricultural system is certainly a worthwhile goal, but it's -- by far -- not the lowest hanging and juiciest fruit to reduce this problem.

text:
Now, there are some things about Climate change I'd like to say before I start the video, just in case they're not covered.  The first is that climate change is not global warming.  Global warming is the belief that Earth is heating up, and it most definitely is, but this in itself is natural.  Climate change is the belief that humans are speeding up global warming, which is also supported with a good amount of evidence.  When I said that global warming is natural, I mean that Earth has spent most of its prehistoric history without any icecaps, and they only appear during ice ages(which we just so happen to be leaving, right now).  

tl;dr
- Climate change is human made, global warming is natural.
- Earth doesn't normally have icecaps.

text: You can't build a sea wall around all of Florida. It would be much easier to put an end to our CO2 emissions than it would be to deal with the effects of climate change, much, MUCH easier. We don't have to give up anything, at all. In fact, our quality of life could be significantly improved by abandoning fossil fuels.
author: PistonAvatarGuy

text:
"only 4% of electricity is made from renewable energy"

That depends on where you are. In the US, it's 15% and growing. !00% of electric production can be done with renewables, as long as storage is included. 

"so heating plastic with electricity won't solve anything"

Except if our goal is to eliminate CO2 emissions, which it is.

"...the same way as electric cars don't make the environment any cleaner because the electricity is predominantly produced by fossil fuels and this is in addition to the highly pollutive lithium batteries."

Except that's not true. Even when being powered by energy that is largely produced by fossil fuels, an EV is still cleaner than a piston engine vehicle, this is because electricity production is very efficient and because EVs are extremely efficient. In my area, which gets 80% of its energy from natural gas and coal, a Nissan Leaf is still cleaner than a Toyota Prius. The batteries also don't add much to the environmental cost of the vehicle, EVs make up for the cost of their batteries within a few years.

" MUCH cheaper than the $100 trillion paris agreement which will only reduce global temperatures by 3 tenths of a degree by the end of the century (delaying it by 8 years)."

But not cheaper than the wars we fight in order to protect oil interests in the middle east. I also doubt that a sea wall could be constructed for $5,000/meter. The Paris agreement was kind of a joke anyway, we need to do more.

"I approach this problem the same way i approach every problem, i take both sides, look at the positives, look at the negatives, weigh up each side and then reach a justified conclusion."

The problem is that you're extremely ignorant.

"and when you look at cost, standards of living and potential lives to be saved which are at the very heart of our government when making political decisions, my solutions beat yours in every category by miles."

Only if you're extremely ignorant of what solutions are being presented.
author: PistonAvatarGuy

text:
"so you come back to me just like every other environmentalist does."

With facts?

Developing countries can adopt green energy just as easily as we can, solar and wind are both cheaper sources of energy than coal, and they're getting cheaper all of the time. There's also no harm in those countries slowing their development in order to make sure that they're developing in a way that isn't going to drive all of humanity off of a cliff.

I didn't dodge anything, I informed you about which option was cheaper. Not only would massively reducing dependence on oil eliminate the cost of military conflicts in the middle east, but it would also save the lives of thousands of American soldiers, save the lives of millions in the middle east, save the lives of tens of thousands of people who die as a result of air pollution in the US, and it would eliminate a major source of funding for terrorist groups.

A global sea wall is FAR from being a realistic solution, and it wont do anything to stop the mass extinction event that has already begun... which is very likely to take the vast majority of the human race with it. 

When combined with storage, solar and wind can supply a huge portion of our electricity, and that electricity  can be used to power just about everything, from our cars, to heat pumps for our homes, to industrial processes. Nuclear is also a great option if we nationalize our grid and improve on the model that the French have been using (with great success) for decades. Hydrocarbon fuels for certain kinds of transportation can be produced from captured CO2 with what is normally wasted energy from nuclear power stations.

Anyway, one way or the other, someone is paying for something, and I think most people agree that the better option is to try to avoid global catastrophe.
author: PistonAvatarGuy

text:
"If it was cheaper then everybody would be using it."

They're starting to, transitions don't happen overnight. Hell, I can look out of my window and see two solar panel installations. The only reason I don't have them is because I rent.

"And why do you think all the richest countries in the world are loaded with oil."

Because we didn't have efficient solar panels or wind turbines for a long time. You might as well be asking why people buy cars instead of horses. 

"Secondly, my point about building a global sea wall was merely a hyperbole, i was signifying that sometimes you have to think outside the box rather than just take the first solution that pops into your head."

I think anyone can see that my solutions are well thought out.

"... you would ask questions!"

And I have, for many years. Clearly, you haven't, because your only solution was hyperbole.

"When making these decisions we need to use facts. No more political hot air, no more media exaggeration..."

I agree, so what the hell is your problem?

text:
I have a habit of turning off the lights,  saving water, not wasting food, not using plastic, not destroying plants since I was a kid because my parents constantly taught me why we need to care about the environment. I have been practicing this things since I was little, I don't face any problem or get irritated. It has become a second nature to me. The way my dad taught me was very effective. He wouldn't just simply say turn off the lights or don't waste food. He would actually teach me that how my action would impact the planet. I remember he use to get the news magazine from around the world. One day I didn't finish my food and he brought this Somalian magazine and showed me the pics of starving people and told me just because things are available to me easily, I should not take them for granted. That was the day and till today I never left even single bite of food. It is important that we teach our kids and make them aware about the climate change and what is our role as a human in keeping our planet save and healthy. 

P.s. I am working towards adapting a zero waste lifestyle.

text:
If the goal is to not use fear and guilt as a motivators due to poor results, why use fear and guilt when abstracting health impact from electricity usage to manipulate people's behavior? 

If fear is a bad motivator, why continue to use the term climate change when it is a scientific fact that the vast majority of people fear change?

Don't preface the video with a virtuous statement about how one is against using fear and guilt, then explain the benefits of how one uses fear and guilt. That's an intentional misrepresentation of oneself in order to be distanced from the label of alarmist.

Conflating the ozone depletion issue with CAGW is dishonest. Stopping folks from using hairspray has nowhere near the impact of stopping folks from using electricity. How many wars were started over hairspray? Not nearly as many as those started over fossil fuels. Modern prosperous societies require electricity, hairspray is optional. Textbook facile argument.

text:
¬†@Lauren Perdulla¬† why would he be joking? People dont want to just not eat meat but give up these common things. Here's an article from beef2live

What comes to mind when you hear the word "beef"?
Perhaps, meat, hamburger, steak or even leather. These are all products of the beef animal (or cattle), but there are also many other byproducts.
Beef byproducts are the products that we get from beef cattle that might not be quite so obvious. For example, soap is a beef byproduct because it uses beef fat.
If you have a beef animal that weigh 1,000 pounds ‚Äì 640 pounds of the animal will be used for meat products, such as steak, roasts and hamburgers. This means 64% of the animal is used for meat. However, 99% of the cow is utilized for meat and other products.
From 1 cow hide you can get 12 basketballs OR 144 baseballs OR 20 footballs OR 18 volleyballs OR 18 soccer balls OR 12 baseball gloves.
If you strung 1 year‚Äôs worth of hotdogs ‚Äì end to end ‚Äì around the world, you would go around the world 16 times!
Leather is a very good example of a beef byproduct.¬†¬†It is made from the cow hide and it is used to make byproducts. Byproducts are a product of the animal that is used as an "ingredient" in other products.
There are many foods that are obviously byproducts, such as steak, roasts and hamburgers. Another more obvious product is milk and other dairy products, such as butterand yogurt.
Name some food products that come from animals. Meat, beef, beef jerky, hotdogs, lamb chops. These are all direct example of food products, but they may be used in tv dinners and lunchmeats.
Did you know that gelatin, what¬†Jello¬†is made from, comes from the connective tissues of the beef animal. So when you eat Jello, you are actually eating an animal byproduct.
Other products that contain gelatin might include gum, fruit snacks like¬†gummy bears, and marshmallows.
Many medical products are made from animal byproducts. Some products may contain stearic acid that is found in fatty acids, such as in beef cattle. Ointments for burns and first aid creams may contain animal byproducts.
Antirejection drugs are used when someone has a heart transplant, liver transplant or even a ligament in your knee to help the body accept the new organ. Animals, such as beef, sheep and swine have remarkable similarities to our own bodies.
Insulin is utilized by diabetics. It can be synthetic, which means that is man-made, but it also can come from livestock.
There is a sticky part on the bandages that can be made from animal fatty acids since fatty acids are used to make adhesives.
Household and office products also may contain beef byproducts.¬†Dog food might include chicken, beef or pork byproducts. Rawhide bones that dogs chew on are made from animal hides.
Laundry pre-treatments contains enzymes¬†‚Äì a protein found in cattle and sheep.
There is a certain kind of china that knick knacks may be made out of that can be made from an animal byproduct ‚Äì bone china.¬†Bone china is made from the bones.
There may be fatty acids from cattle or other animals added to toilet paper to make it soft.
What‚Äôs on the label of the glue bottle? There is a cow on the label of glue because you can use a cow‚Äôs hooves and horns to make glue.
Dish soap¬†may contain beef fat that helps make your hands soft.
Even¬†film¬†contains the beef product ‚Äì gelatin - on the coating of the film.
Candles¬†may have beef byproducts in them to give them more strength, to help them last longer, and make them more opulent.
What would crayons have in them?¬†Probably beef fat, but there is also a kind out now that is made from soybeans.
Paintbrushes¬†can be made out of horse hair, but can be made out of the hairs from other animals as well.
Sports equipment¬†is often made from animal byproducts. Many professional teams use cowhide footballs. So not all footballs are made of pigskin like many people think.¬†Footballs can be made out of both pig skin and beef skin.
Volleyballs¬†can be made from leather, and so can the baseball glove and the outer covering of the baseball.
Industrial use¬†‚Äì many lubricants and fluids may contain beef fats. Some inks used in printing contain animal fats. High gloss printing might contain animal fats.
Industrial cleaners may also include beef byproducts.
Grooming ‚Äì¬†Nail polish remover contain gelatin that helps give your nails strength. Soap, lotions, makeup and lipstick may contain stearic acid, a fatty acid. But not all of them do ‚Äì as some people are allergic to animal byproducts. Some also contain lanolin which is a sheep byproduct. Shaving cream also contains stearic acid, a fatty acid.
Many deodorants contains fatty acids.¬†When people clean their contacts, they use little white tablets called enzymatic cleaners. Enzymes are a protein found in animals.
Saddle soap is¬†used on leather shoes and any type of leather product. It helps leather items maintain softness.
Travel and transportation.¬†Antifreeze may contain glycerol, an animal byproduct. Hydraulic brake fluid and car wax also may contain animal byproducts.¬†¬† Highways are made of asphalt and contain a binding agent made from beef byproducts.
Tires contain stearic acid which helps tires maintain their elasticity.

text: Kudos to Vox and their collaborators for continuing to press the issue‚Ä¶but. The implicit assumptions about policymaking and politics at work here are just absurd. Human psychology has precious little to do with it. To see this, it is enough to ask why so many of us do grasp the urgency and scale of the problem and demand that it be addressed. Or why a large and growing majority of voters recognize the reality and seriousness of climate change. The way humans think is simply not the problem; it's not even a problem. Policymakers simply do not act on the basis of the views and interests of most of the humans they ostensibly represent. The nifty psychological research is a red herring.

Yes, we do, like using facts.  The theory of AGW (Anthropogenic Global Warming, means "man made") is based on "enhanced greenhouse gasses" of which Co2 makes up only about 3%.  Humans are responsible for about 2.8% of that 3%, do the math.  To put it into perspective, the oceans release more Co2 in a single day from a 2 degree change in temperature than we do in an entire year.  In the IPCC reports (which are legislated on by politicians, bureaucrats and corporate heads from multiple nations) Co2 is noted as being the key factor which increases water vapor, which is the main catalyst for change in temperature.  Guess what else the oceans release more of in a day than we do in a year?  That's right.... water vapor.

text:
+philonetic

"I know, most of you don't get it, because you're stupid."

... says the AGW denialist who's willfully ignorant of the science on this topic.



"Co2 is noted as being the key factor which increases water vapor, which is the main catalyst for change in temperature."

There are at least 5 reasons why CO2 is more significant for long-term global warming than is water vapor:

1) CO2 absorbs energy at wavelengths missed by water vapor
2) CO2 has a longer atmospheric residence time than does water vapor
3) Atmospheric water vapor levels are more responsive to temperature changes than are atmospheric CO2 levels; that is: CO2 is a non-condensing greenhouse gas, while water vapor is a condensing greenhouse gas
4) There's a robust, long-term correlation between CO2 and temperature
5) At best, water vapor serves as fast feedback that amplifies the warming from factors such as CO2. Clouds that develop from water vapor, can also act as fast positive feedback or as negative feedback, depending on how high those clouds are in the atmosphere. These effects are important, since CO2-induced global warming has augmented atmospheric water vapor levels, as expected, since warmer air can hold more moisture. So atmospheric humidity increased during the recent period of pronounced global warming (from about the late 1970s to the present), with a humidity decrease during the global cooling / temperature stagnation period of ~1940s to the 1970s.

text: This video may as well be titled "Why some 'experts' are so bad at talking about climate change." We cannot overcome climate change through "behavioral nudges" and trying to change individual and consumer behavior. Significant progress will only be made via putting a price on carbon (i.e. a carbon tax). The responsibility to combat climate change falls much more so on energy companies than on individuals. Energy companies are failing to adequately lead the transition from a carbon-based to a renewable energy-based system. This is where government regulation can, and must, come into play. And this is where individual activism can, and must, come into play. Individuals DO need to act, but in terms of political activism--not in terms of things like using one's electrical appliances less. Individual energy-conserving measures are commendable but ultimately futile in terms of their impact in the grand scheme of things.

author: Reno

text:
Climate change isn't about EVERYTHING getting warmer. In reality, it's only an average of a few degrees difference across the planet. The thing is, this makes everything thrown out of balance. Some places will get much warmer, while others will get much colder; some places will experience decades-long droughts, while others will get record floods, while others get giant hurricanes every year. Imagine a spinning top that starts to slow and begins to wobble unpredictably and wildly all over the place; that is what is going to happen to the climate. 

So what might be going on is that you're living in an area that will experience an increased cooling. In another 100 years, that area might have winters that last months longer than usual and freeze everything solid. It'll be just as deadly as extreme heat.

Global Warming is in relation to a global increase in average temperature (mostly of seawater) of fractions of a degree. This causes radical differences in local weather patterns, which may cause increases or decreases of many, many degrees in different areas. Deadly heat in summers, deadly cold in winters, more frequent and longer droughts and more floods and bigger hurricanes. It's less making weather all over the world warmer, and more making it more extreme in many different ways.

text: As interesting as this is and as impressive as some of these results are, I can't help thinking it's not addressing the bulk of the problem, or the most meaningful solutions. The ozone problem wasn't solved by altering people's behavior. It was solved by laws that eliminated CFCs in refrigerants and aerosol products. People might have used less hairspray, but after the laws went into effect, there wasn't any freon in hairspray anymore anyway. As long as we have a government trying to promote drilling, pipelines and the fantasy of "clean coal", efforts like that described in this video may help, but it seems like a drop in the bucket.

text:
A lot of folks are mad they did not talk about agriculture, please remember that:

A) This is a series that just started, they have 5 more episodes to cover more topics.

b) Talking about agriculture in particular will only be engaging if they have a study or some findings that might turn the conversation from trying to guilt people (which has been illustrated not to work) to something else, like some of the meat-less alternative companies that are popping up. 

Random aside number one, I wish, sincerely, that people were forced to take an undergraduate chemistry class. It would solve so many issues, and you'd have an expert that could address your questions more fully than a science teacher would generally be able to. Environmental chemistry would be better, but that was a third year class when I took mine. 

Random aside number two, please remember that the argument "if everyone went vegan the world would..." is not designed to be a catch all to prevent cataclysm. It would undoubtedly work, but that argument is designed to sway those like me (from a ranching background) to eat less meat, to convince a small percentage to switch to veganism permanently (bravo, people make fun that those people mention it too much, well they damn well deserve it), and to show the rest that something as simple as making better food choices can have a massive effect on the world we live in.

text:
¬†@A. Y.¬† It creates 9% of our co2 emissions but there are more greenhouse gasses. Animal agriculture counts for 65% of nitrous oxide emissions which is 296 times more potent than CO2. Also it accounts for 37‚ÑÖ of all methane emissions which is 23 times more potent than CO2. Also it creates 64‚ÑÖ of our ammonia creating acid rains. Animal agriculture also uses one third of all the land on earth. Also this is causing overgrazing also it is the largest contributor to water pollution from animal wastes, antibiotics and hormones, chemicals from tanneries, fertilizers and the pesticides used to spray feed crops.
In total unites nations has estimated animal agriculture to cause about 15-18% greenhouse emissions when measured as CO2 equivalent. This is higher than the full transportation sector.

text:
One thing most species have in common in relation to the theory of evolution is that they're all adaptive. We humans have lost a lot of our natural instincts, we've grown to become too emotionally attached and deeply fear the experience of the emotions of loss.

Lesser species have no choice, they can't build sophisticated technology so they have to adapt to their environment in order to survive; survival of the fittest. 

Us humans however are emotionally compelled to hold on to the things we've got because we do have a choice, we can build sophisticated technologies. So instead of adapting as a species to fit the environment, we now try to adapt the environment to fit us as a species. And that's where the logic has gone wrong.

Climate change on earth is nothing new, it has wiped out hundreds of trillions of life forms, both land and water, and that's totally normal, it's not an evil sin.

We are only here now because somewhere down the line a sub species of ours perished while we continued to live on, so we owe it to our selves to thank climate change for wiping out our brothers and sisters, and allowing us to live successfully in this climate, we owe it gratitude.

So at what point do we say to our selves that climate change is a bad thing? Climate change is a psychological issue, not a scientific one. Humans have just becomes too sentimental and afraid to let go of things that have ran their course.

You know, the ice caps might melt and we might lose polar bears, but the rise in sea levels might make rivers in Africa run with gold and solve drout completely providing water and rich farm lands, saving millions of human lives. But if we try and modify the environment we might prolong drout or perhaps even make if worse, and extend the ongoing suffering of human life.

It's our fault for building cities on the coast lines, we were young and nieve, and we still are.

author: Storm Storkanus

text:
Rodrigo Mendes  Thank you for bringing up your point about the meat industry, for it is true that they too are one of the primary sources of greehhouse gases. Awareness of that fact is simultaneously encouraging and discouraging, because on one hand, by reducing our consumption of meat, especially beef, we can each do our part in redcing our "carbon footprint."  Eating less animal meat (or hardly any at all or even none at all) is not only good for the environment, it's good for our bodies. But then, I LOVE the occasional steak, you know? I LOVE chicken and pork and lamb and fish , and frankly, I'm not keen on giving those things up entirely.

What's discouraging (besides having to reduce or eliminate all animal meat) is the fact that it's going to be extremely difficult to get a majority of humans to change their eating habits. It's easy enough to buy a car that's fuel-efficient or a fridge that has a great Energy Star rating, but quite another to get people around the world to reduce meat consumption by 90% or 75% or even 50%. And let's not kid ourselves, the meat industry is not going to go quietly into the night. They're going to kick and scream and create adds that will create doubt about meat and its effect on the atmosphere, just as the oil companies do with regards to climate change itself. 

It's going to be a tough road to hoe. But I'm glad you brought it up. The more we know and the more people get "into the know," the better for all of us in both the immediate and distant future.

text: The problem with this article is that it can't expand on any new information on this subject. The entire synopsis of this link is simply " When it gets hot, people can die." We understand this, it isn't new. The issue, is that the presumption is, that every time it gets hot, it can somehow be attributed to man made gases. This entire article is based on this presumed truth. I don't have a hard time believing this. I just can't take it seriously when nobody is willing to make any actual sacrifices to help. It is easy to say "stop eating meat" especially when you are already a vegetarian or vegan. The simple truth is nobody actually cares. Maybe you do I'm not sure, however; when you say essentially "don't worry about utilities" all it sounds like to me is you're not interested in taking the extra step. Perhaps I'm missing something.
author: Andrew Tabish

text:
¬†@Andrew Tabish¬† I'm not saying don't care about utilities, I'm saying that you should focus at least as much on animal agriculture. The article, by the way, is just quoting the study, which uses scientific methods to estimate the relative importance of greenhouse gases in these climate-related deaths.

I'll admit that I was a vegetarian before I started caring about the effect on the environment. But since I got informed (watched Cowspiracy, specifically), I've been cutting down a lot on my dairy.

text:
there is also deindividuation and the bystander effect in play - on a global scale. people may be moved by messaging when they receive it; but when it comes to participating or actualising personal agency to contribute, they feel their contribution is at best minor or even inconsequential.

two parts to this: 1) in large enough numbers and with concerted effort, households definitely can contribute significantly to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, but 2) this requires thousands of households across the world to collaborate in a sustained manner, and their gains could be wiped out by either non-collaborators or increased industrial output - factors completely outside of the participants' control.

while understanding the personal motivations and appealing to human psychology would improve the messaging efforts and lead to some improvement, the larger problem of industrial output and deep-seated habits still remain. should humans cut down on meat consumption? or should the meat industry revolutionise their production methods and manage their GHG output directly? should regulators take bolder steps to control GHG emissions, using both punishments and rewards?

it's probably best if all 3 options are explored simultaneously.

text:
I assume you're in high school? Right now it might actually be a bit boring since you're learning the fundamentals, but stick with it. Chemistry really comes alive once you get to Organic chemistry and beyond to Quantum, Physical, Inorganic, and Analytical. Be sure to get a good grasp on molecular orbital theory and periodic trends, and don't worry about memorizing the table or atomic numbers of all of the elements. When you get to college I'd recommend taking a major in either Chemical Engineering/Bioengineering, or one of the subsets of chemistry/biochemistry. You can also go for a general chemistry major, but be aware that you won't go into some of the topics with as much specificity. 

For now, check out this page, know how to assign charges to molecules using formal charge,¬†get¬†to know¬†how to write electron configurations,¬†and get a good grasp on stoichiometry. The rate laws and molecular kinetics will come in college or AP chemistry if you decide to take it (highly recommended - you'll be able to move right to organic once you graduate), and they involve some calculus.

First go here: http://www.chemguide.co.uk/atoms/properties/atomorbs.html

Then here: http://www.ch.ic.ac.uk/vchemlib/course/mo_theory/

I don't mean to overload you with information, but¬†I sense that you have an interest in the subject, so I thought I might as well send you some useful links! Some of this stuff is pretty profound if you consider the implications.

author: Christopher Dahl

text:
Whenever I hear people talk about "global warming" it reminds of the term "global cooling" I heard from a geology lecture. The professor talked about why he thought "global cooling" is a bigger issue.

If you read about "Geologic temperature record" on wikipedia or some other source, the temperature on Earth cycles up and down in a fairly regular pattern, since like forever. But the recent years (in Earth history scale), the cycle has been broken; it never dipped to a very low point like it was doing for a long long time. Something is holding the temperature high and slowing down the cycle. The fear is that whatever is holding the temperature high (enough for us to survive) won't be holding it forever, and at some point the nature (or whatever is driving the cycle) will make the temperature drop so fast that we won't have enough time to prepare for it, and that could be the end of humanity.

I'm just wondering why I don't hear many people talk about this.

That way you'll feel nice and content you're doing your part, and your focus will be on badgering your neighbours to adopt similar practices, rather than on your representatives to change law.

text: well what about the cows. cows produce so much methane their avarage release of methane a year is 70-120 kg. Methane is a greenhouse gas like carbon dioxide  (CO2). But the negative effect on the climate of methane is 23 times higher than the effect  of (CO2). according to The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United States  (FAO) agriculture is responsible for 18% of the total release of greenhouse gases world-wide.(this is more than the whole transportation sector). Cattle-breeding is taking a major factor for these greenhouse gas emissions according to FAO. Says Henning Steinfeld, Chief of FAO's Livestock Information and Policy Branch and senior author of the report: "Livestock are one of the most significant contributors to today's most serious environmental problems. Urgent action is required to remedy the situation." Livestock now use 30 percent of the earth's entire land surface, mostly permanent pasture but also including 33 percent of the global arable land used to producing feed for livestock, the report notes. As forests are cleared to create new pastures, it is a major driver of deforestation, especially in Latin America where, for example, some 70 percent of former forests in the Amazon have been turned over to grazing.

text:
2764rmouradian: 
My positions on this are not very fashionable, and i'm not a scientist so you should always take what i say with a grain of salt.

But basically i think that we are the major driving force for climate change right now. This seems to be the position of most scientists and ocean and atmosphere studying organizations.

  As for the should we do anything or what should we do about it question, this is a political issue.

 I was a big fan of alternative energies but later on i discovered that they all have their flaws. No energy source is perfect.
 Fossil fuels are an amazing resource and people don't give due credit for their importance in the world we have today. It's just that we overused them. Wind and solar would be the best option to try and mitigate the reducing of use of fossil fuels but i fear it would not be enough to totally replace them. This would mean a change of habits and lifestyle especially in the transportation sector, but this dosn't seem politically, culturally and socially acceptable.

 So what do we get? Denial on one side, and on the other a belief that some magical solution is just around the corner "free energy, thorium, etc.." while everything stays basically the same. We will keep talking a lot about it, but real change won't come because it would be unconfortable even to the average "global warming believer".

 The serious predictions about climate change don't mean the end of the world or human extinction even if we burn all fossil fuel reserves, but they will mean that we won't be able to feed billions like in the world we have today. War, famine, disease , political unrest will drive civilization to it's knees before the climate stabilizes by around the 2300s. we will have a very different world. As for the fauna and flora they will suffer immensely because this is very different to the glacial/interglacial pattern of the neogene/quaternary epochs (the last 20 million years), add the other pressures made by humans with land use and chemical polution/deforestation and we get a very smaller range of animals and plants to live with. New species will eventually come, but this takes millions of years to happen so we will live in a biologically enpoverished world.

 But hey, i maybe wrong. I've been wrong about stuff before.

EDIT: when i say "neogene/quaternary epochs" i should have said "neogene/quaternary periods". epochs would be the Miocene/Pliocene/Pleistocene/Holocene
author: Nuno Foo

text: i forgot to mention: this will take time to happen, florida is not going underwater anytime soon, the IPCC predicts a maximum sea level rise of 1.5 meters by 2100 and that is the worst case cenario, this will start to get really interesting( in a bad way) in the 22nd century

"do you have a heavy science background?"

 No, i quit school very early (not very smart of me), so i'm basically your regular youtube armchair scientist. I've been interested on the subject since an early age and read tons of stuff on the matter, but i don't deserve to be taken too seriously.

"Do you ever want to NOT know?"

Yes! My original thoughts on this were more of an utopian/green/technological future where we solve all these problems with the power of technology but i ran into information that just didn't support that idea and slowly changed my mind. Then i became more of a doomer/imminent extinction/the sky is falling type but again ran into facts that contradicted that, so i had to change my mind again. In the end i got the dull conclusion that i stated earlyer. No utopia or perfect world and no exciting hollywood type end of the world/armageddon/ big finale/ i told you so moment. 

 Thank you for you interest, and don't take what i say too seriously. I'm just a guy on youtube's comment section.

author: Nicholas Veridiculity

text:
They are in fact "things", but climate change will happen no matter what we (as humans) do.  Always has, always will.  I'm all for a clean environment, but the climate is always changing, as the Earth itself goes through various changes.  We humans have this expectation that the Earth should remain static and never change because we have grown used to how things are, but that's not how the Earth works.  Climate change, tectonic shifting, changes in the Earth's axial tilt ... all things that will continue to happen no matter what we do.

Right now the Earth is slowly shedding it's glaciation, and has been for a very long time.  The alternative to that is for the Earth to grow and expand it's glaciation, which would mean the climate is favorable for sending us back into the beginning of a very long ice age.  The idea that we as humans have the power to somehow "tweak" the Earth so it will maintain static climate and static glaciation and NEVER change is just plain silly.
author: Midnight Rider

text:
'Midnight Rider',  No, even with the natural climate change you mentioned, it is happening fast.  From what I've seen, the average climatologist considers man-made CO2 to be the dominate factor in climate change sometime after 1950.  That would mean the warming before that point was primarily due to natural influences, according to their estimates.  Solar activity alone should give us no reason to compound that global warming with our greenhouse gasses, given that what we've experienced in the decades around 1960 is the highest solar activity in over 8,000 years.  It may go down, but I see no reason to expect the Sun to cease its rise in activity at our convenience, especially since we're breaking temperature records in a 100-year solar minimum.

Let me know if you have evidence to the contrary.  Here's a paper addressing the claim about solar activity:
http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v431/n7012/full/nature02995.html
author: Nicholas Veridiculity

text: Ok Nicholas, let's play your game.  How are we going to stop our CO2 emissions?  What exactly is the plan here?
author: Midnight Rider

text:
'Midnight Rider',  Well, now you're asking about political/economic solutions, rather than addressing the science, so it's not really my 'game'.  I'm willing to discuss political/economic solutions, but I can't pretend that I've researched those subjects the way that I have for the science.  Having said that, I'd suggest education is always the way to start.  If people were more educated about global warming, they wouldn't react so ignorantly to it.

Also, I hope you didn't interpret my attempt at correcting you to be an insult.  I don't mince words, but I also don't insult people who are polite, such as yourself.  The fact that you haven't resorted to insults indicates that you're probably smarter than the average Youtuber, so I'm not looking to burn that conversational bridge.  I just seek to either learn or teach.
author: Nicholas Veridiculity

text:
What I meant was that if people lowered their meat intake to something less wasteful, then that would mean more people could eat less, as opposed to less people eating more. This would not directly affect the growth of the food supply, but rather be a more efficient use of it. Since population (not necessarily fertility, assuming you mean the birthrate) directly correlates to how much food is available, this would cause greater long-term growth, but would still eventually peak, because more people = more food consumption.

TL;DR: Theres too many people, and soft-rationing the food supply would only delay the inevitable stagnation.

author: Janus Van Massenhove

text:
Animal agriculture sets free carbon that has been incorporated in plant matter months ago, and is part of the normal CO2 circulation. In short, a balance of plant growth and grazing animals alone is carbon net neutral. Yes, if you look at the entire volume the number is huge, but it balances out with the plants grown for feeding the animals in the first place. The only thing that isn't carbon neutral is getting the meat to the consumer and cooking it.
The transportation industry sets free CO2 that has been taken out of circulation and scrubbed from the atmosphere millions of years ago.
author: Nikolaus

text:
+Nikolaus
Not really, it's true that growing plants and burning them is essentially CO2-neutral, but farming Mays, Soy and whatnot for animal feed does output more greenhouse gasses. Tractors require a lot of fuel to drive, plough the earth and harvest the crops. The plants themselves need to be transported to factories that combine them into feed, which in turn gets transported to the animals. Moreover the other negative effects of farming are present as well, i.e. overfertilisation and use of pesticides. On top of that, land use itself is far bigger for animal agriculture than for grains/vegetables since the animals themselves also need a lot of food, so in densely populated areas like Flanders/The Netherlands this is really important to take into account as well.

text:
Bad air quality in urban areas such as China (in the intro of the video) IS NEITHER A CAUSE NOR A CONSEQUENCE OF CLIMATE CHANGE!!! It is a problem of public health which is different.
People living in dense cities concentrate pollution but the denser the city the less people pollute per capita. For example in France, air quality is terrible in Paris compared with rural areas or smaller cities. However people living in Paris actually pollute a lot less on average (they use their individual cars less, live in dense buildings with smaller heat losses etc.). The poor quality of the air is because however parisians on average cause less pollution, their high number in a small area means they have much less air  per capita to dilute the pollution they create.

STOP MIXING HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES, it gets everyone confused.

text: I agree with this idea of competitiveness, however I think one key point is being missed. I find showing solutions to a problem motivates people to act. If leaders offer solutions to the problem of climate change, people will follow and adopt the solution. I like to take on the example of Tesla where owning such a car is considered cool and fashionable; the solution has been adopted. Solutions are what pushes people to change, to improve and to live cleaner. Here are some solutions for instance: ecolonomy, an economy that works in a cyclic way, or perhaps the vegetable gardens in the midsts of small british towns. How about planting more trees in cities to filter the CO2? How about making cities more walkable so that people use a bike or their feet rather than a car? There are already so many solutions people do not know about, and these solutions would push change in our society to become more eco-friendly.

text:
Disregard conspiratorial reasons.  The number one reason it's not brought up as often or even along side efforts to curb carbon emissions is because it's a much more difficult problem to tackle.  Trying to solve the issue chemically, from the position of the livestock, hasn't been fruitful enough, so that leaves dealing with the psyches and bodily health of billions of omnivores.  Weaning large populations off of secondary factors of life is difficult, but doable, because as long as the outcome still leads to access to the same primary factors, it may not even be that noticeable of a difference.  But food, a primary, is different.  Because it's so difficult to even begin to work logistics, it gets back-burnered, at least until efforts with carbon are more successful.

This is unfortunately a very political issue and takes political measures.

Conserving energy is definitely a great step towards curbing climate change but what about animal husbandry (worse that using electronic appliances, cars, trains, aeroplanes‚Äã combined) that is still the leading cause of climate change. Our increasing demands for meat, eggs and dairy has lead to cutting down trees to grow animal feed, animal abuse to increase rapid production and methane gas from cow fart, all leading to global warming, water and air pollution, wild animals and sea animals extinction. If we don't take responsibilities right now we are going to leave this world with a huge debt for our children and grandchildren to pay for no fault of theirs. "Be the change you want to see in the world" and that includes both me and you.
