text: I disagree with that method of presentation - 1. Present the crisis, and 2. Placate concerns with stories of a few solar farms in Montana.  The response to date has been nowhere near what is necessary to reduce CO2 emissions. They continue to rise, in absolute terms, year-on-year.  If we're to get to zero CO2 emissions by 2050, which is what is necessary in order to maintain 1.5 degrees warming, we'd need to be at 30% of current emissions by 2040, 60% by 2030, and 90% by 2020. We'll likely be at +5% at the end of this year.  We're cooked.

text: I think showing energy use is good but it needs to be framed right. It has to be shown with the higher numbers representing less usage because people naturally want to see numbers tick up. It's why idle games like cookie clicker work at all as a game. I recently got a new car that shows me my average mpg. When I first started driving I watched it a lot and even then I was around 31 mpg on average. Since then my car has essentially trained me to be more mindful of that and now it comes naturally and I'm sitting at an average of almost 40 mpg and it was such a natural progression that I hardly realized that the way I was accelerating and decelerating had changed entirely. Putting in a system like that would play to psychology and almost make a personal game out of getting the highest numbers.

¬†@EMPulse¬† I went vegetarian because I don't like the taste of meat, anyways: You can't tell people to entirely stop eating meat. I'm not going to go through the trouble of linking studies no one will read but, last time I checked, processing some broccoli doesn't increase my chances of getting colorectal cancer by 20 or so percent. This is also assuming 1. everyone can afford organic meats 2. the meat industry is going to have a sudden change of heart and change their farming practices so everyone can have safe meat and 3. that there is enough time and resources to be able to provide the world's demand of food with organic meat (spoiler alert: there isn't). It is also irresponsible to use billions of pounds of grain to feed animals so you can have burgers when you can instead feed the starving men, women, and children of the world. And yeah,  I agree nuclear is affordable and less dangerous, and yes cutting on coal and oil is nice, but that takes time, legislation, and a lot of capital that won't show up overnight. But as of now, the easiest thing you can do, right now right now, is go vegan.

author: Galaxian Studios

text: Our teeth and jaws aren't made for eating meat. Yes, we have the ability to eat meat with our teeth but just because we have canines doesn't automatically make us omnis. 2 issues with the whole canine thing 1. We have only FOUR canines out of 30-something teeth and they aren't even that sharp; you can't cut your finger with them whereas a true carnivore (say a dog or cat) can pierce your skin. And 2. A lot of herbivores have canines, like gorillas, some deer, hippos, and some other animals too; having canines doesn't automatically make us omni/carnivores. Additionally, our jaws can move side to side, whereas a dog, cat, tiger, etc. can only move their jaws up and down. Also, the development of atherosclerotic plaque is another indicator of us being herbivores. Only herbivores can develop plaques in their arteries. Dogs, cats, and animals meant to eat meat never will (unless you remove their thyroid for some reason) develop plaque build up in arterial walls. There are various other indicators like the length of our digestive tracts that indicate we are herbivores, you should look it up.

text: It's not about veganism and whether humans are meant to eat meat or not. This is about how much destruction mass producing livestock causes. The cows we breed alone produce more than two billion pounds of manure nitrogen per year. Studies can tell you that animal agriculture is the leading factor of polluted waters. You can feed 800 million people with the grain that we feed to livestock. Meat production is responsible for roughly 20% of greenhouse gas emissions. The water we give to these mass produced livestock use half the water consumed in the country (USA). 260 million acres of land is used to produce feed for livestock. This is where veganism comes into play. Yes I agree in the Stone Age and whatnot eating meat was necessary to survive but that's because it was a necessity. Today it is not a necessity. Back then they didn't have supermarkets/grocery stores. Today we do and it carries all the food you can imagine. The amount of harm we are doing to the environment is not worth a burger, bacon, or those "all-you-can-eat" wings. Especially when there's so many other options right in front of you. And if you can't give up those things, try eating plant-based "meat". Similar flavor, minus the harm of the animal and environment :)

text:
The problem with finite resources is that they run out.

BP estimated we had 53.3 years of oil left as of the end of 2013. There is a lot more (difficult to extract) oil that can be unlocked, but you won't be happy with how much it's going to cost.

The World Coal Association says proven coal reserves will run out in 2130 worldwide.

Fossil fuels are going to become seriously expensive as we run out. Meanwhile, the cost of solar panels + batteries keeps dropping and the technology keeps improving.

author: rugbyguy59

text:
Problem: Burning too much fuel causes global warming, which is bad. Solution: Burn less fuel.

Well, if we burn up all our fuel, we won't have any left for airplanes and spaceships, so I'm fine with burning less fuel. And if appliances become more energy efficient then I'll save money on my electric bill, so I gain something from people trying to solve this problem. Because I'm ok with the solution to the problem, I have a rather low bar set for what evidence it takes to convince me that global warming is a thing. But if you told me that the problem were bad enough that I would have to give up fuel entirely all the meanwhile we hadn't replaced it with something else yet, then I would need a lot more evidence before I would be willing to agree that global warming is a real, terrible thing and we should all go back to living in caves without propane or electricity, in order to stop it.

Usually I don't go out enough nor pay enough attention when I do go out to remember whether it was hot or cold even yesterday to notice the trends in average temperature where I live, so when I hear people say that the world is warming up, I have to decide whether I believe the person speaking or not, because I certainly don't know from my own experience what's going on in my own locale, let alone worldwide.

text:
IntarwebUser: Of course no individual can tell if the climate is warming. We must rely on data and methods available. Of course, numerous other changes are being observed (changing growing zones, migration of plants and animals, melting ice, etc) that confirm the measures. Unless we go full conspiracy theorist the best evidence we have strongly indicates we are seeing, and will continue to see, very rapid warming. One degree Celsius per century is very rapid and is likely to speed up. Pure pragmatism means we should be taking this very seriously.
There is also no reason to think anyone is saying we end up living in caves. Alternative energy could supply most of our needs if we built enough of it in its current form. We might not be able to fly around anymore but that hardly equals living in caves.

author: Avoo93 R

text:
+Mytheroo

"and this is why you fail. The argument is CATASTROPHIC ANTHROPOGENIC global warming (CAGW) has not been demonstrated sufficiently"

That's just a straw man you contrarians use to misrepresent mainstream climate science, akin to how many creationists use the phrase "molecules-to-man" to misrepresent evolutionary biology:

Another claim advanced by those who reject the mainstream scientific agreement on climate is that the consensus position consists of a claim of catastrophic anthropogenic global warming or the frequently used acronym CAGW [...]. However, CAGW is rarely, if ever, defined or sourced to a mainstream scientific organization or study. Any scientific study‚Äôs result, or statement by a researcher, that does not fit a contrarian‚Äôs personal, flexible definition of CAGW can therefore be adopted as ostensibly supporting their view and refuting the mainstream, even when such results are actually consistent with the mainstream position on climate [...]. 
[...]
Additionally, we find that catastrophic anthropogenic global warming [CAGW] is essentially a term that is never used in the relevant scientific literature by mainstream sources. Furthermore, in the press it appears to be used exclusively by climate contrarians. The term is typically neither defined nor attributed to a mainstream scientific source. Our conclusion is therefore that CAGW is simply a straw man used by climate contrarians to criticize the mainstream position (50)."
https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-20161-0_3



"The questions are do humans cause the bulk of this warming and is it catastrophic? The 97% consensus group were not asked that question."

Again, because that's a vague straw man you contrarians made up.

There's an evidence-based scientific consensus that:

A1) There has been global warming since the mid-20th century.
A2) Humans [largely via anthropogenic greenhouse gases] caused most of this recent warming.
A3) Most of the recent [or near future] climate change is [or will be] caused by humans.
A4) Climate change is a serious problem and/or a danger to humanity.

The following sources document the consensus on A1 and A2:

Table 1: "Consensus on consensus: a synthesis of consensus estimates on human-caused global warming"
"Does it matter if the consensus on anthropogenic global warming is 97% or 99.99%?"
Page 49 of: "Models, manifestation and attribution of climate change"

For the consensus on A3 and A4: 

Among AAAS (American Academy for the Advancement of Science) scientists with relevant expertise (PhD earth scientists current working), there's a 95% consensus that climate change was a serious problem and a 93% consensus that recent warming is mostly caused by humans:

"Earth Scientists Views on Climate Change"
http://www.pewinternet.org/2015/07/23/elaborating-on-the-views-of-aaas-scientists-issue-by-issue/

And in another survey, ~87% of climate researchers thought that humans caused (or will cause) most of the recent (or near future) climate change, while ~86% of climate researchers thought that climate change poses a very serious problem and/or a threat to humanity:

Figures 88 (v043) and 2 (v007) of: "The Bray and von Storch 5th International Survey of Climate Scientists 2015/2016"
https://www.hzg.de/imperia/md/content/hzg/zentrale_einrichtungen/bibliothek/berichte/hzg_reports_2016/hzg_report_2016_2.pdf



"currently the empirical data needs a fudge factor of multiplying what we know by 3 times in order to get the models to create the claimed future change."

If you're talking about positive feedback, then yes, that does applying CO2-induced warming. But not, it's not just a "fudge factor". It includes evidence-based conclusions regarding surface albedo, clouds, water vapor, etc. I discuss that further here:

http://blamethenoctambulantjoycean.blogspot.com/2017/09/myth-no-hot-spot-implies-less-global_15.html

Climate models actually tend to under-estimate that positive feedback, and thus under-estimate how much global warming will be amplified in the future. For instance:

"Climate Sensitivity in the Geologic Past
[...]
Proxies for CO2 and temperature generally imply high climate sensitivities: ‚â•3 K per CO2 doubling during ice-free times (fast-feedback sensitivity) and ‚â•6 K during times with land ice (Earth-system sensitivity). Climate models commonly underpredict the magnitude of climate change and have fast-feedback sensitivities close to 3 K"



"The problem with the science, and the message, is that if you plug in the numbers we have into the models, there is little to no change. They found that the numbers needed to be 3 times bigger to create the effect that was desired, and then set about attempting to explain that this 3 fold increase in the empirical data was valid due to "forcings"."

No. The direct forcing from CO2 yields roughly 1.1K of warming per doubling of CO2. That is amplified by three-fold to ~3K due to feedbacks, not forcings. These feedbacks include positive feedback from water vapor, clouds, and reduced surface albedo. These are included in the climate models. For example, see figure 5 of this paper:

"Positive feedback in climate: stabilization or runaway, illustrated by a simple experiment"
https://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/full/10.1175/BAMS-D-14-00022.1

text:
That's not true either. In a natural ecosystem, sure, but no one's talking about that. Animal agriculture is incredibly destructive to the environment because they don't move around. They stay in one place and food is brought to them while waste keeps being funneled into the same fields of waste. Enormous numbers of animals are bred and raised in the smallest possible space. This is not how animals evolved to live.

40,000 years ago when there were large herds of giant animals pooping all over the place the earth could handle it because herds MOVE. The land was all grass, trees, rock and dirt. There was an ecosystem that could support life and kept a balance. Agriculture as we know it today does not concern itself with the land or the life around it. All it cares about is how to maximize the economic viability of the land and that's a totally different thing.
author: Chris Countryman

text:
Blake, I don't disagree with any of that. And I'm not sure what I said that you disagree with or think I was wrong about. Yes, raising animals produces CO2 but it's less than energy production- something we can actually fix and people are generally on board with. I don't even want to get into the water consumption because we'll just go off on a tangent, but, yes I am aware of that fact.

And, yes, there are more people, cows, pigs, chickens, etc. My point was there were millions of large herd animals prior to global civilization and their presence alone did not significantly tip the scales of the climate; certainly not with the speed we're changing it now in any event. That was in response to someone above claiming that "animals do not create pollution." Bullshit they don't. The difference is how they live that determines the effect of their pollution. Humans and their waste are subject to the same laws and effects.

Be wary if hedging your bets on the statement, "If everyone just did X the world would be saved." If everyone just became vegan, if everyone just rode their bike, if everyone turned their lights off all the time, etc. These plans simply do not and cannot work. Any plan that hinges on people being better people is doomed to failure. People can be counted on to be selfish, ignorant, argumentative, and resistant to change. Plans to avert society from disaster need to accept that reality and plan accordingly.
author: Chris Countryman

why don't we try finding new ways to deal with our problems? I see the same subjects being talked about over and over again and it's always about the same things. people just running around in circles, using the same responses and answers to problems that could have already been solved. 

there ARE different ways of solving the same problem. we could make it easier to eat less meat instead of going "cold turkey" like finding good vegan and vegetarian options to mix with our current meat eating habits.
we could change the way we farm that's more eco friendly. for example hydro and aquaponics are good options for farming lots of food without using nearly as much water or space. aeroponics for example uses way less water than even those two forms of farming and all of them have higher and faster yields then farming in dirt. 
we could find ways to use the current waste our current systems do make. maybe all this manure and gas we are making could be used as biofuel. we wouldn't need to harvest oil from the ground if we combine it with other means of energy like solar, wind and water.
we don't need to be stuck, we can unstick ourselves from our old habits and change. we are humans, we are good at adapting and using our brains.
so let's use the brains we were born with and see if there is a way that WILL work. in reality, we already have the answers to our questions, we just have to be open minded enough to find them and actually use them.

text:
In case nobody mentions this to you specifically, it's important to understand that there are inert (when it comes to absorbing sunlight) forms of gases and chemicals, and forms that actively absorb heat from the sun. Grass is an inert (in this context) form, and breaking that food down with the acids and bacteria in a cow's stomach releases the very active (in this context) methane gas. 

Your line of thinking would indicate that burning gasoline is a circle with no pollution, since all of it exists in nature... It forgets that you are turning something that does not affect the climate (oil, which is a bad example because it's a carcinogen, but it does stays in the ground and rarely poisons anyone anymore since the easiest oil to find is no longer near the surface) into something that does affect the climate (carbon dioxide).

Actually China is the biggest producer of greenhouse gases in the world along with developing countries who dont the resources or political stability to use cleaner methods of power production. Animal Agriculture contributes about 16% of global greenhouse gas production (GGGP) and Industrial Processes contributes around 65% of GGGP.

Heres a list of the GGGP:

Agriculture (Animal): 16%
Industrial Processes: 65%
Forestry/Land Use: 11%
Nitrous Oxide: 6%
Fluorinated Gases: 2%

Sources:

https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/global-greenhouse-gas-emissions-data

text:
Rx  "...climate change" which was occurring in hot and cold cycles long before humans were around." True, but each time the earth heated or cooled, there was always a reason. Just as there are reasons why it gets hot in the summer and cold in the winter, there are reasons why the earth has heated up at times and cooled down at others. These things don't just "happen" out of the blue, without an underlying cause. In fact, the causes of those past periods of rising and falling temperatures serve to underscore how sensitive the environment is to change.

Check out this link. There's lots to explore and find out about. You are not incorrect with regards to "cycles' - they do exist. But what causes those cycles? And can humans have an effect on those cycles or on the earth directly, despite the cycles? Find out for yourself. I'm sure you'll find it interesting.

http://ossfoundation.us/projects/environment/global-warming/natural-cycle

CO2 is a result of global warming not the cause. intergalactic radiation (forming clouds that reflect suns heat) are pushed away by solar winds (increased solar activity from flares, hot spots) allowing more solar energy to be irradiated, warming planet, which then releases more CO2. graphs show amazing correlation of sun activity then global temp increase, then CO2 rise. text: +Lookitup The thing is... what you are talking about is based off of one factor (and yes, the C02 thing in general is 1 factor as well but...) The issue isn't "There's more C02 thus we screwed!" the issue is that because of deforestation, the artificial addition of massive amounts of C02, the increased (based on what you just said) amount of C02 being produced naturally, and other factors combined are simply not... in synch with how the planet tends to handle things. It's too fast and it's also more than the cycle usually handles. High C02 cycles have occured before, and it wasn't a boon to all life... not really. It was a boon to some forms of life, but certainly not all of it.  Those cycles happened over much longer periods and for vastly different reasons. That is what the concern is.

text: Vox is a liberal driven media spreading propaganda. It feeds you what you want to believe. If you really crave for genuine unbiased information you wouldn't be here. First, science is not determined by consensus. The 97% number was debunked countless times. Second, anthropogenic climate change is not a proven theory. There are many factors as to why. For example, the unreliability of climate models. They have been run dozens of times and often they failed against observations. Add that we have little to no understanding of factors such as ENSO or Milankovitch Cycles which contribute zero substance to models. Third, climate change is a non linear process. You simply cannot predict it let alone come to a conclusion that global warming is caused by human contribution of CO2.

text:
It's also interisting how you can see the original claim evolve over time, when you trace it back to it's source:

Daily Mail: 
Arctic ice has increased by 50% between 2012 and 2013, but it's still among the lowest measurements in 30 years, without indication of a reversal in the long-term trend.

Breitbart: 
Arctic ice has increased by 50% between 2012 and 2013, but it's still among the lowest measurements in 30 years, without indication of a reversal in the long-term trend.

Townhall:
Arctic ice has increased by 50% between since 2012 and 2013, but it's still among the lowest measurements in 30 years, without indication of a reversal in the long-term trend.

And this ladies and gentlemen is how the internet turns actual science into complete and utter bullshit.

text:
Filip Jakacki Sorry to tell you this, but Canada's federal carbon tax hasn't actually gone into effect yet. Perhaps the province you visited might already have fully implemented one, but that's a different story and these taxes are usually designed to be revenue-neutral, in which the money goes toward making low/zero-emission cars cheaper and improving public transport in areas where it's lacking.

Also...climate change isn't just everything getting progressively and permanently warmer, which is why it's not 'global warming', and freak weather incidents aren't an indicator of much of anything on a long-term scale. That's why US Senator Jim Inhofe's idea to bring a snowball into Congress as 'proof' that climate change was a hoax made him an utter laughing stock. Today it randomly decided to start snowing here in Vienna after weeks of sun and rain, but that doesn't mean that the oceans aren't dramatically acidifying, sea levels rising and winter ice caps rapidly shrinking.

What pollution does have an immediate effect on is the air we breathe and water we drink. Is it not a good idea to reduce our emissions simply for those two, essential things, if not for the longevity of the planet/human race?

And electric cars are indeed happenning, espcially in places like Norway (which has very far distances between population centres, I should add), where the (concervative) government is providing heavy incentives for EVs. And considering that the cars are now nearing 300 miles of range (which is wholly adequate--a human can't really go more than that without needing to stop anyway), it's not going to take 30 years to get to 500+ range. That's a bit silly.

text:
"Global warming" gives people the idea that the whole planet should be warming up at a consistent rate, which just isn't how climate change happens. It leads people to stupid conclusions like "It snowed today, so how can global warming be real?" Or, where I live, "It's been cold in spring, how can global warming be related to this?", nevermind the fact that we've also surpassed the previous record high spring temperature this year.

"Climate Change" is more accurate, because "climate" specifically refers to weather conditions over a long time. It also doesn't specify "warming", which is good because, despite warming being the overall trend, some regions will initially become colder as ice melts.

text: Oceans will rise as continental (not oceanic) ice caps melt - Antarctica and Greenland being the two big ones. Oceanic ice caps such as the one at the north pole melting will have no immediate impact on sea levels. Oceanic ice caps melting will increase temperatures further through feedback effects, however, due to the fact that ice reflects more sunlight than water.
author: Abahrelghazali

text: Well, ice is less dense than water, so it expands and floats; the floating prevents the sea level from retreating, because ice which is normally above the surface, not displacing any water, while in ice form, will end up at or below sea level when it melts. That doesn't cause sea level rise though; it balances out, so the seas won't rise from sea-ice melt. The problem is land-ice. Mountain Glaciers and the Ice Sheets of Greenland and Antarctica are normally not displacing any water, but as they melt, the liquid will end up adding to the ocean's total volume, hence, sea level rise.

text:
+Zoe Phin 

Sun does drive temperature. The problem is that molecules like CO2 make the sun heat up the earth twice instead instead of the sun's ray hitting the earth and bouncing back into space. 

IDEALLY: The Sun is suppose to shine its rays on earth- some energy gets absorbed, but most gets reflected back into space.

PROBLEM: CO2 and other molecules act as a glass ceiling forcing the rays of light that where on their way out of the earth to bounce back onto the earth a second time. This will create unnecessary heat. We don't want this heat. It will cause a whole litany of problems and changes. 

I think it is a mistake not to recognize the molecules creating the green house effect and just oversimplify the sun as the main charge of climate change. Esp since most of the effects are being hidden by stratospheric pollution.

text:
S Azizi , you're describing a perpetual motion machine, like this: http://www.ilovemycarbondioxide.com/images/IPCC_oven.png

I'm familiar with the fake physics that the youth is indoctrinated with, unfortunately it's all fake.

https://arxiv.org/abs/0707.1161
"The atmospheric greenhouse effect, an idea that many authors trace back to the traditional works of Fourier (1824), Tyndall (1861), and Arrhenius (1896), and which is still supported in global climatology, essentially describes a fictitious mechanism, in which a planetary atmosphere acts as a heat pump driven by an environment that is radiatively interacting with but radiatively equilibrated to the atmospheric system. According to the second law of thermodynamics such a planetary machine can never exist. Nevertheless, in almost all texts of global climatology and in a widespread secondary literature it is taken for granted that such mechanism is real and stands on a firm scientific foundation. In this paper the popular conjecture is analyzed and the underlying physical principles are clarified. By showing that (a) there are no common physical laws between the warming phenomenon in glass houses and the fictitious atmospheric greenhouse effects, (b) there are no calculations to determine an average surface temperature of a planet, (c) the frequently mentioned difference of 33 degrees Celsius is a meaningless number calculated wrongly, (d) the formulas of cavity radiation are used inappropriately, (e) the assumption of a radiative balance is unphysical, (f) thermal conductivity and friction must not be set to zero, the atmospheric greenhouse conjecture is falsified."
